For this project we will need roughly £2,500 in order to create our pilot episode. This is a break down what the money will be spent on: 

As stated above a big chunk of this money will be going towards building our sets where we will need to buy big furniture such as armchairs, tables, beds etc. also needing to provide costumes for the characters. We are hoping to sauce these from local charity shops and online as a way of saving money, however this could still get expensive. 
Additionally, paying our actors for this project will take up a large sum of the funding, as we would like to have experienced and well suited actors this means paying them a fair rate across a filming week. Due to having 2 main characters and 3 side characters this will bump up our costs. However as our story is very character driven, we believe it is important to have those more experienced as a way to illustrate this through actors. 
Any remanding money will be donated to our local care homes, specifically one that will be used in our episode, to hopefully go towards helping better their experience in the care homes. 
Those who contribute to our project will receive a credit at the end of our episode, with a complimentary gift box which will also include a hard copy of the episode as a thank you for your donation. 

 
                                    
 
    Georgia Weaver - Producer 
With having had previous experience in producing for other films and television shows, I took a real interest in creatively organising a project and realised I love producing. I hope to use these skills to make this a fun and innovative sitcom pilot that everybody will enjoy.
 
   Emily Montyn - Director 
I’m Emily and I’m the director of our sitcom pilot. I wanted to take on this role as it’s something I have not yet done during my time at university but always wanted to do. It may be ambitious taking on such a demanding role for this project, but I am taking the necessary steps to ensure that myself and my team will succeed with our plans for our final project.
 
   Jade Sheldon - Director of Photography 
I’m Jade, the Director of Photography for this sitcom pilot. Unlike other projects I have worked on such as Swipe Right and 50PH13, this project will require me to manage a small team of camera operators to ensure thorough coverage to catch all the best moments both scripted and unscripted.
 
   Annabel Thomas-Gay - Production Designer 
I’m Annabel the Production Designer for the sitcom pilot, Veronica’s List. I have only previously taken one this role once for the short film, Swipe Right, therefore I am excited to face new challenges that come with this role. Alongside this I am keen to carry out any research that may help me along the way in order to create a well-designed set for the pilot. 
 
   Tom Kennedy - Editor 
Having studied Film and TV for over 8 years and specialising within the creative departments of film, I have opted to undertake the editorial role for the TV sitcom ‘Veronica’s List’. This will be my first time stepping up to the given job title for a TV studio production, bringing new challenges and experiences to light. I am looking forward to the tasks ahead whilst also striving to achieve a unique, visual aesthetic with my aims as editor.
 
   Evelyn Iulia Dicu - Sound 
I’m Evelyn and I’m the Sound Operator for the sitcom pilot. Being a sound operator is challenging for me because I’ve never done it before. I’ll work hard to make sure everything will go smoothly for our graduate project.
 

Thank you for getting this far, we understand that not everybody is able to donate money, however there are other ways in which you can help us. 
Like our Facebook page where you will have access to: 

Teasers 
Posts following our journey
Exclusive Q&A videos with actors and crew 
Behind the scene photos and videos 
Interactive sign up to create your own bucket lists to share to your friends and family. 

Don't forget you can also share our indiegogo page with friends and family, getting our project out there will really benefit us.  
Thank you!

story:
﻿

 

We’re in the midst of a revolution.

 

At a time when most independent, specialized businesses are being pushed into obscurity by an overly monopolized, global economy, craft beer is flourishing.  This evidenced by the juggernauts Anheuser-Busch, MillerCoors and Heineken [which composed of 90% of the total beer market in the 2000s] experiencing steep declines, yet brewery jobs are at an all time high.  People are drawn to craft breweries because of the commitment to higher quality ingredients, unique flavor profiles and because they all begin the same way - as a labor of love which makes for a great story.  

 

Crafted seeks to celebrate these brave brewers by showcasing not only their hops but their stories on a national level so they can reach a broader audience.    Each season we will chose 4 different breweries and one beer from each to sell in a multipack that consumers can buy directly.   It’s our hope that by bringing these stories and their inspired brews into the living rooms of enthusiasts, we can foster a crafted culture.  

 

Founders

 

Craig Chapman - Producer & CEO

I have 20 years of experience in New York as a production manager working for MTV, VH1, Nickelodeon, Logo, and more. I currently produce a series on Amazon Prime called Real Food Real Kitchens that is all about family, food, culture, and history.

Christopher Berger - COO

I have a decade of experience in the food and beverage industry educating patrons on brewing styles, locations and ingredients in craft beer. Additionally, I have 5 years of experience in commercial sales and marketing.
 

Mission 

 

Crafted will revolutionize the way people are able to experience and try new craft beers from breweries all over the country. Viewers will be able to watch the Crafted digital series that tells the stories of four different breweries each season. They will then be able to order and try a mix-pack of beer that features one beer from each brewery featured in a season of Crafted. 
 

FUNDING GOAL - $5,000

 

 

Most of the funding we are raising will go towards start-up expenses for Crafted. These funds will provide us with all the necessary tools to make this a success. 


$500 - e-commerce platform / website hosting and domain for the first year. 
$300 - business cards and small swag items (stickers etc...)
$1,000 - legal expenses for contracts, release forms, terms of service etc..
$600 - travel expenses - we will need to take two over night trips to the Tampa area and South Florida to shoot the series.
$200 - beer packaging retail license so we can buy and ship mix-pack packages
$2,100 temporary office / shipping space
$300 - Contingencies = 5% of total budget
 

Perks

 

 

While our perks are non-tangible, they are huge on bragging rights. You will be able to tell friends and family that you helped support an all new concept for people to experience and try new craft beers. You could even share one those new beers with them while watching the episode and showing them your name in the credits.

 

 Why should I care?

 

 

If you are a fan of craft beer and the culture and community that surround, Crafted will be an especially exciting project to you. Your support will go to help create a one of a kind series that explores the passion behind craft breweries, and break down decades old barriers that have prevented craft brewers from getting their creations in to the hands of fans outside of their immediate geographic location.

 

Track Record 

 

Our producer Craig has an incredible track record working on tv series and feature films for 20 years in NYC. He has worked as a production manager for MTV, VH1, Nickelodeon, Time Inc.... and as an editor for InTouch Weekly and Seventeen Magazine. He has also produced digital series and content on Hulu, Amazon Prime, the MX Player, Facebook Watch and more.

 

Turning a Profit 

 

 

Although we will be producing Crafted on a tight budget. We love telling stories of passion and emotional commitment and Crafted nails each one of these triggers for us. We will be shooting and editing the entire first four episode season with the belief that the response we will get from craft beer enthusiasts will be astounding. Our payment will come from making an engaging and amazing series that will pay off with substantial viewership and mix-pack sales. 
 

Risks and Challenges 

 

Crafted is an all new concept that is charging headfirst in to an untapped business model that is full of firsts. Crafted is part digital series, part craft beer e-commerce opportunity that presents a risk that is unmeasured and can’t insure our success. 

We are facing this challenge knowing it will be difficult to navigate but also know it has the potential for huge success. We believe the rewards will outweigh the risks.

 

Other Ways to Help

  

Even if you can't contribute any coinage, you can still support Crafted. Follow us on social media and share our Indiegogo campaign on your own social media and with friends you think might like the series by using the Indiegogo share tools on this page at the top.
 

Thank you for your support!

story:
Hello, everyone! We are excited to announce that we will be holding an open mic/improv fundraiser show on Zoom ft. stellar Bay Area talents! Please support the cast and crew of Hellacious Affair, a spy comedy, in ONE HELLACIOUS NIGHT. Admission to the show is FREE, but donations are very much welcome! All proceeds will go toward the production and distribution of our web series.

We will also be holding a drawing where you can win awesome prizes. Each attendee will get an automatic entry and donors will get entries based on a tiered system. 

Please enable us to share our gifts and talents with the world. We truly believe this show is something special, and we can't wait to bring it to you! 

 

With love and solidarity,

Hellacious Affair Cast & Crew

---------------------------------------------------------------------

About the web series

Hellacious Affair is a spy comedy web series created and written by David-Henry Bennett (MFA, Academy of Art) and Lora King (MFA candidate, Academy of Art). The show follows Henry, a top (but clumsy) spy agent, as he teams up with a new (and slightly neurotic) partner while showing her the ropes. As they get to know one another, they work to try to save the world from a dangerous drug, set to be released and kill millions of people.

Hellacious Affair is a completely collaborative project meant to entertain and showcase diverse, three-dimensional characters of different races, sexual orientations, and backgrounds. We aim to increase representation through our work and submit our series to different festivals.  

How will our donations be used?

All funds will go toward the production (e.g., materials, safety measures, hiring talent and crew, etc.)

Thank you, and welcome to our journey!

story:
About "I met someone" 

"I Met Someone" follows three friends, Kim, Tara, and Ronnie as they move through emotional turning points in their romantic relationships. 

Kim, the mother of the group, is a people pleaser who tries to hold everyone up while forgetting to stand on her pedestal. She finds herself unsatisfied after entering a polyamorous relationship with her boyfriend Mike. 

Tara, the baby of the group, comes from a wealthy and loving family. She aspires to find that "perfect love" that her parents had and finds herself pressuring her boyfriend into marriage.  

Ronnie is the fun and energetic friend of the group. She loves to live life on her own terms and isn't willing to commit to much because "it doesn't fit her free spirit." Ronnie begins a secret relationship with Tara's cousin Ebony, against her friend's wishes. 

The girls all try to hide what they're dealing with out of fear of embarrassment. Throughout this journey, they learn the importance of sisterhood, truth, and self-reflection. By meeting one person, they are all forced to see their imperfections and need for growth. 

 

The Impact

"I Met Somone" tackles many subjects like building trust in friendships, identity crisis, commitment issues, and more. The writing aims to start a conversation about what accountability looks like in our romantic and platonic relationships. As a Black Queer writer and producer, I want to create more stories with social commentary about the plights and beauties of the Black community. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your contributions will be used to pay the cast and crew, rent equipment, secure locations, purchase PPE materials, crafty, props, costumes, and cover some of our post-production costs. 

By donating to our production, you can receive a variety of perks like a producer credit, live BTS footage, early access to episodes, entry to win a free sweets table from Pastries by Pat (view menu), or I Met Someone merchandise (hats, shirts, hoodies, and phone cases).

 

Meet the Team

 

Mark D'Neal (Writer/Producer)

Mark D'Neal is a writer and producer from the Southside of Chicago, IL. He first gained an interest in television at a young age and aspired to be a news anchor, later graduating with a BA in Broadcast Journalism from Columbia College Chicago. While attending school, Mark landed internships with CNBC's "American Greed" and the local talk show "Windy City Live." 

During undergrad, he worked as a barista at a coffee shop in downtown Chicago. The vibrant customers and coworkers he met were so unbelievable that he felt a need to write a script about them. This resulted in his first production "HER cafe," a mock reality show and comedy about a group of baristas who loathed working in the service industry. Mark would later go on to write and self-produce the short film "Dinner with the Robinsons," a feel-good comedy about two brothers who bring their unlikely partners to Christmas dinner. Today, Mark continues to write more screenplays while working full time on the upcoming AMC series "61st Street" (2022).

 

Anastacia Davis (Director)


Anastacia C.C. Davis is a God-fearing writer/director, content creator, and Founder + CEO of Finesse Factory. She seeks to highlight stories from her multicultural experiences, create art that breaks stereotypes, and speaks to the complexities of everyday people. 

Anastacia earned her MFA from Full Sail University in Film Production, and BA in Theatre Arts from her beloved HBCU Alabama State University. Upon graduating from Full Sail Anastacia garnered experience and credits in the industry working for Chance The Rapper, The NBA, American Idol, Empire, Refinery 29, HGTV, and more. Her recent projects include the Mary J. Blige Documentary, "My Life" (2021), PBS Documentary, The Black Church: This is our Story, This is Our Song, Sundance Film Festival & YouTube Orginal Film "Life In A Day" which has garnered over 16 Million Views. This past spring, Anastacia's short film, an open love letter to her HBCU, was selected as 1 of 4 Grand Prize Winners for the TBS #HBCUCashOutContest winning her a grant of $25,000.

Anastacia currently works for AMC Network as the Art Department Assistant for the upcoming Michael B. Jordan produced show 61st Street (2022). Outside of filmmaking, Anastacia creates content for A-List celebrities, brands, and corporations. Her work has been featured on Good Morning America, TBS Network, Out Magazine, Blavity's Afro Tech, and more. 

 

Toya Poore (Director)

Toya Poore is the screenwriter behind Revolution, a short film she starred in, wrote, produced, and directed. Having experienced multiple traumatic events as a young girl growing up on the southside of Chicago, LaToya shares some of her trials through her writing. A lifelong storyteller, LaToya specializes in crafting drama-filled stories with heaping doses of realistic conflict that are impactful and original.

 

Shei Nicole (Director)

Shei Nicole is a full-time entrepreneur in the entertainment industry. She began her journey at Purdue University where she obtained her Bachelor's degree in radio/television media communications. Classes like scriptwriting, television production & film production sparked an early interest in what would be one of her leading passions today. 

Shei directed her first music video in 2018 & has directed many other music videos with local Chicago artists. She has also produced & directed other digital content including The Dish Nation Chicago Minute with Tone Kapone & Specific Sites with Bree Specific. Mark gave her one of her first opportunities to co-direct when producing his short film "Dinner with the Robinsons." Her goal is to gain a deeper presence in the film industry with more documentaries, digital series & movies. To check out more content check out her website, www.ShutupShei.com 

 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Share our campaign with your friends and family. Follow us on Instagram @imetsomeone_webseries and like our Facebook page! The more people we can reach, the closer we can get to our goal.

story:
WHAT IT'S ABOUT

Middle Class Snacks is a sketch comedy series made up of short episodes and, brief, punchy sketches. The show will be full of twists and turns, callbacks, wacky characters, and unique concepts. 

OUR GOAL

We want to make a hilariously funny sketch comedy show that appeals to a wide range of audiences. There's something for everyone. This is going to be a fun show that you'll enjoy from beginning to end. We are striving to create a show with beautiful production value while also being goofy. Think "I Think You Should Leave," Tim Robinson's Netflix show.

WHAT WE'LL USE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR

The biggest part of the contributions will be used to buy food for our lovely cast and crew. Feeding everyone keeps us happy and ready to work hard, but boy, does it add up fast. We'll also be using contributions to buy all kinds of props, costumes, and supplies for set design. After shooting and editing is all said and done, we plan on sending this project off to festivals! Those are not cheap, so your contributions will help with that tremendously.

story:
"Why doesn't that show exist yet?"

I've been developing the "Be The Change with Rebecca" concept for almost two years now. The show came as an answer to many of my own frustrations. I came to realize that community engagement is my only cure for a 21st century news-cycle hangover. But it's not only me: the more I step out into communities across the US, the more I see that it's actually the folks who are tackling local problems head-on who have an easier time sleeping these days. Why is that?

Maybe it's knowing that the world really is full of nice, caring people (and that you're one of them). Maybe it's the genuine human interaction that we miss out on in our age of social media. Maybe it's the priceless reward when selfless efforts pay off.

Whatever it is, I see it everywhere. Now, I want others to see it. And then I want them to feel it.

As soon as I began reaching out to nonprofits, filmmakers, and friends about the idea, most everyone I spoke to was left wondering, "Why doesn't that show exist yet?"

So, what's the show about:

  • Community organizer Rebecca Kassay dives into dynamic volunteer opportunities at a wide variety of nonprofit organizations while traveling across US in an old RV with her husband and their dog.
  • While engaged in that day's volunteer work, Rebecca chats up fellow volunteers and serves as an avatar for viewers to explore the whos, whats, whens, wheres, whys, and how-can-I-get-involveds of that nonprofit and volunteer role.
  • Ranging from tears of laughter to solidarity in a somber silence, the show captures the profound experiences shared by strangers who roll up their sleeves to work together.
  • "Be The Change with Rebecca" aims far beyond attracting an "audience": its goal is to empower its viewers (yes, that's you!) to realize that they, too, have what it takes to make positive changes in their own communities.

The show is inspired by: the format of Dirty Jobs with Mike Rowe; the immersive, raw journalism of Vice News; and the real-people, real-story feel-good vibes of The Ellen DeGeneres Show.

We know we've done our job when an episode ends and you're excited to be connected to a similar opportunity in your region. We will be coordinating with national service organizations to provide you with the best resources for use on your path to your own unique community engagement story. Our hope to help connect more volunteers with the nonprofit organizations that have been waiting for them just down the street, turning our viewers into doers!

We're Volunteering, Too!

The Aureate Visuals production team is passionate about the concept and will be donating a ton of their time and equipment for use on the project. Of course, as the host and executive producer, I'll also be donating my time, the use of my RV and motorcycle, and covering many related expenses out of pocket.

That being said, there are still many costs associated with the project, like gas for the RV, hiring local crew-members at each filming location, and feeding the team. This Indigogo campaign helps to raise money for 8 full-length episodes of "Be The Change with Rebecca", to premier in Spring 2020. Here's a rough breakdown of our minimum budget:

  • $3,000 - Travel/lodging
  • $3,000 - Local Crew Wages
  • $1,500 - Food/Per diem
  • $500 - Miscellaneous Expenses
  • $800 - Indiegogo related fees

Everyone has plenty of 'things', so in exchange for your generous donations, we want to offer you something more meaningful than a keychain or a t-shirt. Our perks are all about YOU. (If viewing this on a phone, be sure to click the bold title to read more about the perk.) Has a nonprofit in your community done well by you? Show them some love! Do you want to get more into volunteering but don't know where to start? We can help with that! Want to be on the show? You got it!

The best perk of all? The show being produced!, and passionate people doing cool things makes great TV, so you'll get to brag that you were a part of making this awesome series come to life.

To supplement these funds, in addition to all other budget items (specialized equipment, post production, etc...) we are seeking collaboration with sponsors- to be announced as we get closer to filming! If we don't reach our entire Indiegogo goal, we're still aiming to film this year- I'll just pity my crew if we run low on food funds and I become hangry. Eek.

If (when!) we exceed our goal, we will start planning ways to make production and post-production even greater, and you can be sure that we'll start pulling out the stops on fabulous new perks! (Maybe we'll even bust out some celebratory keychains.) We already have additional production crew-members in mind who we would hire (your dollars going right back into the American economy, and helping to tell volunteers' stories with more technical beauty), and if ya'll are really feeling it, maybe we can film a couple of extra episodes to capture a few more forms of community engagement in this season.

As the funds behind "Be The Change with Rebecca" grow, so does our scope of imaginable possibilities. Thank you in advance for giving what you can to assure success as "Be The Change" launches into the mediasphere!

Your Voice ALWAYS Matters!

If you're struggling to make the rent this month, don't worry about donating right now, but if you have another minute, here are some other ways to help the project out:

  • Spread the world about "Be The Change with Rebecca". It is a show about communities, and so it needs a big ol' community behind it! Tell people who volunteer, people who've never volunteered, people who work at nonprofits, business owners, politicians, the dogs at the shelter you volunteer at- tell everyone who might dig it.
  • Follow us on Instagram @bethechangewrebecca or Facebook at  www.facebook.com/bethechangewithrebecca/
  • Repost the Indigogo crowdfunding page link on your own social media pages for all to enjoy.
  • Do you have a talent that you'd like to contribute to the project? Are you on the east coast and want to volunteer on our film crew for a day? Get in touch!

To Wrap It Up...

We're a team of positive, effective, passionate people who are making a show that shows you how and why to use a few hours each month to make a positive change where you live. Why are we doing it? Well, when many more people start to do this, the whole world will begin to change- for the better, very quickly. And we're pretty sure that everyone would like that.

We so greatly appreciate the support, trust, and enthusiasm that you're sharing with us. Hope to see you out there!
story_txt:
"Why doesn't that show exist yet?"
I've been developing the "Be The Change with Rebecca" concept for almost two years now. The show came as an answer to many of my own frustrations. I came to realize that community engagement is my only cure for a 21st century news-cycle hangover. But it's not only me: the more I step out into communities across the US, the more I see that it's actually the folks who are tackling local problems head-on who have an easier time sleeping these days. Why is that?
Maybe it's knowing that the world really is full of nice, caring people (and that you're one of them). Maybe it's the genuine human interaction that we miss out on in our age of social media. Maybe it's the priceless reward when selfless efforts pay off.
Whatever it is, I see it everywhere. Now, I want others to see it. And then I want them to feel it.
As soon as I began reaching out to nonprofits, filmmakers, and friends about the idea, most everyone I spoke to was left wondering, "Why doesn't that show exist yet?"
So, what's the show about:

Community organizer Rebecca Kassay dives into dynamic volunteer opportunities at a wide variety of nonprofit organizations while traveling across US in an old RV with her husband and their dog.
While engaged in that day's volunteer work, Rebecca chats up fellow volunteers and serves as an avatar for viewers to explore the whos, whats, whens, wheres, whys, and how-can-I-get-involveds of that nonprofit and volunteer role.
Ranging from tears of laughter to solidarity in a somber silence, the show captures the profound experiences shared by strangers who roll up their sleeves to work together.
"Be The Change with Rebecca" aims far beyond attracting an "audience": its goal is to empower its viewers (yes, that's you!) to realize that they, too, have what it takes to make positive changes in their own communities.

The show is inspired by: the format of Dirty Jobs with Mike Rowe; the immersive, raw journalism of Vice News; and the real-people, real-story feel-good vibes of The Ellen DeGeneres Show.
We know we've done our job when an episode ends and you're excited to be connected to a similar opportunity in your region. Do you want to get more into volunteering but don't know where to start? We can help with that! Want to be on the show? You got it!
The best perk of all? The show being produced!, and passionate people doing cool things makes great TV, so you'll get to brag that you were a part of making this awesome series come to life.
To supplement these funds, in addition to all other budget items (specialized equipment, post production, etc...) we are seeking collaboration with sponsors- to be announced as we get closer to filming! If we don't reach our entire Indiegogo goal, we're still aiming to film this year- I'll just pity my crew if we run low on food funds and I become hangry. Eek.
If (when!) we exceed our goal, we will start planning ways to make production and post-production even greater, and you can be sure that we'll start pulling out the stops on fabulous new perks! (Maybe we'll even bust out some celebratory keychains.) We already have additional production crew-members in mind who we would hire (your dollars going right back into the American economy, and helping to tell volunteers' stories with more technical beauty), and if ya'll are really feeling it, maybe we can film a couple of extra episodes to capture a few more forms of community engagement in this season.

story:
Summary

We all love Superheros. They stop the bad guy, rescue the hostages, save the day, and get... depressed??? Well, yea. Unfortunately, 1 in 5 adults living in America battle with some form of mental health condition. This includes superheroes like our very own Xerxes Hughes, better known as Captain Zero. That does not mean, however, that they're cr**y or out of their mind.

Media is how we shape the word. It's how we’re informed about what we see, what we talk about and most importantly..how we talk about it. We're creating this show to bridge the gap between perception and reality when it comes to mental health/depression--especially how it's viewed/talked about in communities of color

 

Show Content 

Our goal is to tell a unique story that will bring awareness to and eliminate the stigma surrounding social issues like mental health. Episodes primarily revolve around Xerxes and his maturation as a hero. How he deals with his newfound “celebrity” and trying to balance his hero life, social life, and depression. Other episodes follow supporting characters as they navigate through themes of self-discovery, self-acceptance, race, sexuality and more.  

  •  10 Episodes in season one
  •  30 minutes long
  •  4 seasons outlined 
  •  Potential for hour-long specials detailing the backstories of characters

 

What We Need

We know what you're thinking. "Cool idea, but isn't a hundred grand a bit much?" It is, but we set a big goal because we have big plans. We don't just want to talk about it, we want to create real-world change. 

The campaign funds will serve two purposes:

  1. We are pledging to donate the first $25,000 to two mental health organizations: National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) and Mental Health America (MHA). The $12,500 we raise for each organization will go towards education, support, and awareness on the behalf of individuals living with mental illness and their families.
  2. The remaining money will go toward paying staff, covering animation costs, covering the cost of the awesome perks we're giving away, business/legal fees, travel costs, and funding community events that help our cause.

 

The Perks

In return for your invaluable contributions and support, we have some specials perks lined up! We've got T-Shirts, hats, hoodies, signed hand-drawn posters, personal meet and greet with the creator, and even a chance to voice a role in the show! (See the Perks page for more info) 

 

The Impact

The solution to depression is a two-way street. We need individuals better at detecting the signs of depression and mental illness and we need those who are afflicted by it to feel comfortable enough to talk about it so they can seek treatment.

The creator of the show Lamard Cher-Aime was diagnosed with MDD (Major Depressive Disorder) when he was fifteen years old.  Throughout his journey of battling with mental health, he wanted to use his passion for art, storytelling and his own personal experiences to give a realistic depiction of depression and what it’s like from the perspective of a person of color dealing with mental health issues (Which is so rarely depicted in modern media). With the ultimate goal of reducing suicide rates among teens and young adults. 

 

Risks & Challenges

As with any business venture or creative work, there is always a chance things won't work out as planned. Our biggest obstacle is money (obviously). This is our first large-scale project as an independent studio but we've made some great partnerships like the casing agency UTA, Casting directors over at ABC/Disney and various other Networks and talent agencies who believe in our vision and have helped us along the way. 

 

Milestones

  • Five Actors attached to the project (King Bach, Eliza Coupe, Haha Davis, Zolee Griggs)
  • Pitching to eight Major Networks (Netflix, Hulu, Warner Bros. Media, Comedy Central, BET, HBO, FXX, Adult Swim) 
  • Secured an animation studio to create the project (VML Morris Inc.)  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in the position to help but no matter what situation you may be in, spreading the word about this campaign and what we're trying to accomplish. The more people we reach, the bigger voice we have and awareness we can bring to this subject. Great stories don’t just entertain us. They teach us.  A good story tells us about our world, what wrong with it and why we should care. A great story charges us with action. To go out into our imperfect world and want to right the wrongs we see in our society. To dare to be a hero. To save a life. Even if the life you save, is your own.

You can also be a source of encouragement to others and share the importance of mental health. For more information on this subject please visit Mental Health America at www.mentalhealthamerica.net or National Alliance on Mental Illness at www.nami.org.

story_txt: This campaign has ended. Thank you!

story:
Resonance is a short doc series surrounding music venues in Toronto that no longer exist. We will create 5, four-minute episodes. Each episode will focus on one particular venue and will tell its story through a combination of archival footage as well as interviews with artists who have played at the venue. Our project will focus on venues that have opened and closed between the 1950s and the early 2000s. 

The venues that we will focus on are:

  • Maple Leaf Gardens
  • Riverboat Coffee House
  • The BamBoo
  • We'ave
  • Masonic Temple

Resonance is being produced by Momentum Digital Productions, which is our group of 4th-year Media Production students from Ryerson University. We began pre-production in February 2018, and have completed a comprehensive, 163-page production plan with original scripts, and an extensive budget. With your support, we are excited to begin production in October so that we can submit our final project by December.

 

Alison Tubosa - Producer and Director

Allison Tubosa is the director and producer of Resonance. Originally from Toronto, Allison now resides in Mississauga, but her passion for music is still very much alive. Growing up in a musical household, she aspired to be a writer, a figure skater, a journalist, but is currently a young creator who wants to meld all her passions (including music) into her work. She hopes Resonance will help viewers connect with not only their community, but some (old) new music!

Nicole Landry - Videographer

Nicole has gained experience in filmmaking through hands-on courses taken in the Media Production program she is enrolled in at Ryerson University, as well as through participation in documentary projects covering social, political, and environmental topics. As a 70s classic and progressive rock fanatic, she is looking forward to working on a project that brings her love for documentaries together with her love for music and history!

Faizan Valimohamed - Technical Producer

Meet Faizan, the man who has committed his semester to sit in his bedroom edit Resonance videos. Faizan has had a passion for editing videos since he was 11 years old, and he also loves playing and listening to music. In high school, he played alto and baritone saxophone in his school's jazz band. When he's not editing, he's usually working his other passion, Esports events!

Jessica Persadie - Audio Lead

Jessica Persadie is the audio lead of Resonance. Throughout her undergraduate program at Ryerson University, Jessica has developed a passion for audio and music production. Her passion continues to grow along with the rise of Toronto’s music culture. This docu-series allows Jessica to explore her fascination with Toronto’s music history and culture!

Liana Mallia - Marketing and Logistics

Liana has always had a passion for music and history, and she's excited to use her past experience in marketing, social media, writing, and digital media to make this project a reality. From running social media accounts for a small business within Toronto, to creating digital content for multi-platform television networks, she is excited to use what she's learned to shine the light upon the history of Toronto's music scene!

Your generous donation will go towards the costs of production, festival submissions, craft services, marketing, and distribution. Because we are able to utilize industry-level equipment through Ryerson University, we are able to keep our budget low, however making a web-series isn’t exactly affordable on a student budget, so every contribution is greatly appreciated. Our executive team has already contributed a considerable amount, and we have crunched the numbers with great attention to detail, and have taken all considerations into account.

Not able to donate?

That's totally fine! There are other ways that you are able to help Resonance come to life. By spreading our story on social media, you will help increase awareness about our project! 

Instagram

Facebook

https://www.resonancetoronto.com/

story:
WHAT IS SEX CAFÉ?

Sex Café is an unapologetic conversation web series featuring women discussing female sexuality, gender equality, and everything that comes with it.

The purpose of the show to have women share their authentic opinions, knowledge, and experiences in relation to their sexualities. It's the sex-ed and gender studies class you wish you had. We want to include as wide a range of experiences and life personalities as there are women.

The first season of this mini series follows four episodes, each under 10 minutes. An episode will feature three different women and an individual set of corresponding topics with funky backgrounds.

Our inclusive conversations have addressed topics such as:

  • The Current Political Climate as a Woman
  • Female Sexual Health Education
  • Reproductive Rights and The Affordable Care Act
  • The Male Perspective
  • Culture and Sexuality
  • Online Dating and Online Sexual Perception
  • Conversations with Queer Women
  • The Porn Industry and Women in Pornography
  • A Conversation About Consent

 

THE CREATORS AND CREW

Before I talk about myself and my co-creator, I want to highlight our amazing team. This show would not exist without our crew for the 12 episodes we’ve filmed thus far:

  • Cinematographer: Katherine Hoskins
  • Sound: Manuel Ermecheo and Cedric Wilson
  • Art Directors: Celina Arslanian, Perri MacKenzie, and Tabitha Swanson
  • And so much love to everyone who helped with the shoots!

So now a little more about us. We are two female creators based in New York City. My name is Dasha Kova and I am the co-creator and producer for Sex Café. My background is primarily in writing and content creation, however I have been a web series fiend for a while and noticed that there was a serious lack of conversations supporting women’s sexuality. I wanted to create a show that would act as an open space to lead and normalize these types of discussions in as candid a way as possible. We decided to include playful sets to make the conversation just as fun as it is important.

Next, we have the show’s co-creator and co-producer, Goldie Poll. She’s a skilled multimedia journalist and research queen. Her work experience includes both qualitative and quantitative research, management, and lots of academia. One day I asked her if she wanted to work on this project, and two years later we’re still at it and excited to keep going!

 

HOW ARE WE DIFFERENT?

Sex Café’s bold name does not go unnoticed. Such a provocative title often requires clarification: we are not a sex show, we are a show about sexuality. We do not scare away from taboo topics, we engage the discussions involving them with hope to create a new normal around such themes. We are a production made by women with women in mind. Don’t worry, we include men too! Recently, we filmed our one-off male perspective episode and it was exciting hearing their thoughts on set.

 

WHY GET INVOLVED?

We are fortunate to have been in graduate school while starting this project: this meant renting equipment and studio space could be done without an extreme budget, however, we’re heading out into the “real world” now and the show cannot keep going without a budget. We have 8 pre-filmed episodes that have yet to be edited in post-production and we need your help to fund the software, equipment, and (wo)man hours it will take to edit the next seasons, as well as keep the show going for future filming!

We would also love to be able to pay (and feed) our entire team for any work they do going forward. We are dedicated to do the best shoot we can with the budget we have, and from pre-production, production, post-production, editing, equipment, studio, food, and transportation... This entire production takes a lot of time and $$$. We are dreaming of being able to fund and support the project and team.

In future seasons we are looking to feature topics such as:

  • Debunking some orgasm myths, and what’s more fun than a good orgasm
  • Queer Sex
  • Things I wish someone had told me about pregnancy and childbirth
  • The Trans Woman’s Experience
  • A Millennial's Guide to Menopause
  • Examining the Female Gaze

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP: 

We understand that not all can contribute financially, but we can still use your help:

  • Pitch us topics
  • Help with general outreach
  • Help us build our community by sharing
  • Volunteer:
    • Crew time
    • Merch printing
    • Food catering
    • Advertising

...THAT'S EVERYTHING! 

We are currently at the forefront of this content online and would love to have you as a member of our community. If you’re interested in creating a sex positive world for the women around you, please get involved in this project in any capacity.

Sending you all the utmost gratitude! See you soon.

 

With love and haikus,

Sex Café Show Team
story_txt:
WHAT IS SEX CAFÉ?Sex Café is an unapologetic conversation web series featuring women discussing female sexuality, gender equality, and everything that comes with it.The purpose of the show to have women share their authentic opinions, knowledge, and experiences in relation to their sexualities. It's the sex-ed and gender studies class you wish you had. We want to include as wide a range of experiences and life personalities as there are women.The first season of this mini series follows four episodes, each under 10 minutes. An episode will feature three different women and an individual set of corresponding topics with funky backgrounds.Our inclusive conversations have addressed topics such as:
The Current Political Climate as a Woman
Female Sexual Health Education
Reproductive Rights and The Affordable Care Act
The Male Perspective
Culture and Sexuality
Online Dating and Online Sexual Perception
Conversations with Queer Women
The Porn Industry and Women in Pornography
A Conversation About Consent
 THE CREATORS AND CREWBefore I talk about myself and my co-creator, I want to highlight our amazing team. This show would not exist without our crew for the 12 episodes we’ve filmed thus far:

Cinematographer: Katherine Hoskins

Sound: Manuel Ermecheo and Cedric Wilson

Art Directors: Celina Arslanian, Perri MacKenzie, and Tabitha Swanson
And so much love to everyone who helped with the shoots!
So now a little more about us. We are two female creators based in New York City. My name is Dasha Kova and I am the co-creator and producer for Sex Café. My background is primarily in writing and content creation, however I have been a web series fiend for a while and noticed that there was a serious lack of conversations supporting women’s sexuality. I wanted to create a show that would act as an open space to lead and normalize these types of discussions in as candid a way as possible. We decided to include playful sets to make the conversation just as fun as it is important.Next, we have the show’s co-creator and co-producer, Goldie Poll. She’s a skilled multimedia journalist and research queen. Her work experience includes both qualitative and quantitative research, management, and lots of academia. One day I asked her if she wanted to work on this project, and two years later we’re still at it and excited to keep going! HOW ARE WE DIFFERENT?Sex Café’s bold name does not go unnoticed. Such a provocative title often requires clarification: we are not a sex show, we are a show about sexuality. We do not scare away from taboo topics, we engage the discussions involving them with hope to create a new normal around such themes. We are a production made by women with women in mind. Don’t worry, we include men too! Recently, we filmed our one-off male perspective episode and it was exciting hearing their thoughts on set. WHY GET INVOLVED?We are fortunate to have been in graduate school while starting this project: this meant renting equipment and studio space could be done without an extreme budget, however, we’re heading out into the “real world” now and the show cannot keep going without a budget. We have 8 pre-filmed episodes that have yet to be edited in post-production and we need your help to fund the software, equipment, and (wo)man hours it will take to edit the next seasons, as well as keep the show going for future filming!We would also love to be able to pay (and feed) our entire team for any work they do going forward. We are dedicated to do the best shoot we can with the budget we have, and from pre-production, production, post-production, editing, equipment, studio, food, and transportation... This entire production takes a lot of time and $$$. We are dreaming of being able to fund and support the project and team.In future seasons we are looking to feature topics such as:
Debunking some orgasm myths, and what’s more fun than a good orgasm
Queer Sex
Things I wish someone had told me about pregnancy and childbirth
The Trans Woman’s Experience
A Millennial's Guide to Menopause
Examining the Female Gaze
 OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP: We understand that not all can contribute financially, but we can still use your help:
Pitch us topics
Help with general outreach
Help us build our community by sharing
Volunteer:
Crew time
Merch printing
Food catering
Advertising


...THAT'S EVERYTHING! We are currently at the forefront of this content online and would love to have you as a member of our community. If you’re interested in creating a sex positive world for the women around you, please get involved in this project in any capacity.Sending you all the utmost gratitude! See you soon. With love and haikus,Sex Café Show Team

story:
Note: Animations in Pitch NOT Final! They are samples from the graphic novel with the dialog added. Thanks!

 

So... What is This Thing?

Space Destroyer Hunter is the spinoff of Starship Moonhawkthat takes the series in a whole new direction. It follows Captain Skye Cobalt and the crew of the USAS Hunter as they explore the desolate and deadly Osiris Region. Originally conceived as a series of graphic novels, "SDH" has become much more, as it will be the launchpad series for our new Moonhawk Network of programming. This pilot is the jump-off point for a fully animated series of adventures, but before we can do that, we need to prove to our potential investors that we can make the first episode. It is our "proof of concept", if you will.

We don't yet have actual animation, but this is similar to what we are planning and is a related project:


Rachael Harrison played by Olivia Brown, animation by Kage Productions/Tiffany Lei, background by Larry Cathey

What Will I Get?

We have an amazing array of options available to prospective investors, including producer credits, digital downloads of the graphic novel, ISOs of the completed film (so you may watch it in full 1080p on your computer or burn to disk and play on your DVD/Blu-Ray player), cast interviews and even the option to come aboard my podcast, "Moonhawk Studios Presents" and speak to the cast and crew directly!*

But, more to the point, you will be helping us to make a roughly 30-minute film starring the vocal talents of some amazing industry professionals, as well as some newcomers, from a series that has been 25-years in the making!

The Impact

"Space Destroyer Hunter" will be a unique blend of classic Japanese animation ("Anime") influences with much of the animation techniques used in shows like FX's "Archer", all created in Anime Studio/MoHo, with 3D elements rendered in Maya. We hope to bring you a visual representation like no other since the combination of these visual mediums is so uncommon.

Risks and Challenges

The risks and challenges are many, but we want this to be a positive experience for all. Plus, we want to be able to bring our players back to do the next volume and the next after that. In order to make that happen, we must be successful with this, our first endeavor. I've never undertaken a project of this scope before, so I am sailing into uncharted waters. The good news is that I have an experienced team of professionals led by Co-Executive Producer William Long, Animation Director Nathan Bonner, with character designs by Christine "Mayshing" Chong and Sound/Special Effects by Keith W.  I feel that under their guidance, we will be able to bring you a truly unforgettable story experience.

Hopefully, with your help, we can make this a truly magical experience for everyone. Thanks again for your support!

Michael C. Prokop
Creator, Space Destroyer Hunter

Nathan Bonner's Indavo 2.0: The Animation! As he will be Lead Animator, we will be aiming for something a bit like this, but even more refined because we will be working with a team of four, and not a one-person army.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some folks are simply unable to contribute money themselves, and that's ok! You may help us in other ways by spreading the word far and wide. Let's share this all over the Internet. Also, don't forget to use the IndieGoGo sharing tools as well.

 

Breakdown of Funds (How We Will Spend the Funds):

$10,000 - Principal Animation, Soundtrack, Backgrounds, Character Designs
$3000    - Actor Salaries
$2000    - Administrative Budget (Advertising, cost overruns, etc.)

Stretch Goals?

Coming Soon!

story:
About this project:

As the creator and director of this project, I have personally invested my interest in seeing the show succeed. I have 11 years experience in the industry, shooting my first feature film back in 2007-2008. Variety and the Hollywood Reporter, as well as other film related magazines, released articles about my ability to create from nothing and shoot on tight budgets.

This project is set up to succeed! With cast members from popular shows like One Tree Hill and The Vampire Diaries, it will appeal to a wide audience as well as create an entirely new audience of its own.

Your contribution will go a long way in helping the episodes get produced and be the best they can be! We have set up specific perks that will even allow you to be a part of this ground breaking new show by offering walk-on roles, title credits, and many others! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Our Main goal is to hit $30,000. This will cover the cost of production for the remaining 5 episodes. That comes out roughly to around $6,000.00 per episode, and is the bare minimum.

We are looking to expand beyond that, and take our production value even further. On the minimum, we will have everything we need to do the basic shoots, but as we begin to hit our stretch and expanded goals, we will be looking to set up at the sound stages at EUE Screen Gems Studios in Wilmington, North Carolina. The most efficient way to shoot our episodes, is to build the sets within the sound stages so that we have the capabilities to shoot on a proper schedule, and have everything available to us to be able to produce quality content.

By choosing a perk that we have offered up, you can help us make a successful show, not only for this first season, but for ongoing seasons. The key thing is we need your help to ensure we meet our goals.

With the first goal being set at $30,000, we should be able to reach that goal quickly. Anyone who has produced a show, knows that it's extremely expensive without the help of large studios. If we do not reach our goal, we will in our best effort, attempt to continue filming and shoot everything we can to try and complete the season based on whatever amount we were able to raise.

The Pilot episode is already shot and completed. We were able to get it done on a minimal budget, and it gave us a sample of what we can do when everyone comes together and pours their passion into a project. It also gave us the confidence to know that we can shoot out an entire episode, quickly, efficiently, and most times under budget. All without sacrificing quality production value.

 

THE CAST

 

 Vaughan Wilson - (One Tree Hill)

 

 Ryan Williams (On Air)

 

 David Schifter (Homicide Hunter)

 

 

 

As always, with film there is risk involved. Luckily crowdfunding has become a way to make something happen, without having too risk your entire life savings to "make it, or break it". We can all come together and with even enough people donating as little as a single dollar bill, we can do things that we're possible ten years ago.

One of the hardest things to secure on a project is distribution. Knowing that you are shooting for a purpose, and your project will be seen, is always a motivational guide. We have several options for distribution already in place that all expand through the digital streaming realm and beyond! The show WILL be seen. 
 

 

We understand that not everyone can afford to even do a single dollar. All we ask is that if you stumbled across this, and couldn't contribute, but yet you find our project interesting and worthy, then please by all means, share this. Pass this information on to your friends, your family, your social media, and where ever else possible. Who knows? Maybe someone else who sees this because of you, ends up grabbing a nice perk for themselves. So PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE, remember to share, as we are counting on everyone as a whole to make something from nothing.

story:
Hello, I’m Kayleigh Miles

  • I am a film & tv student, I created my own company called “Inspire Generations Media.” I love to film, direct and act. 
  • My Campaign is to create a unique drama that is Dark, gritty and beautiful. It is important to me because I want to show off creativity and inspire many.
  • I wish to bring a certain kind of community together who love vampires and to influence and collaborate with many talented people. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise: £500 

  • This money will go into Props & costumes and will help get this series up and going on it’s feet. You will get to feel like you are apart of the series and we will state how much you have helped us and would be forever grateful. 
  • I am a very creative person, so this series will have a fantastic effect, but the cast are very talented and they will be what makes this a very impactful series.  Also when I was a child I used to always say “When I grow up, I want to be a vampire.” I can imagine going back in time to little me and telling her about this project, I bet she would be amazed. 
  • If we do not reach the full goal, that is okay because we are very optimistic and are positive that we will reach a fantastic outcome, we will create a small saving to put the money towards props and costumes. We will go behind the scenes so that you can see what the money has gone into. 

The Impact

  • This will be valuable to you because it will create a perfect vision and also make you feel like you are involved because you are apart of this experience too.
  • I have their successful projects such as: Roses are red (A feature length film to raise awareness of Domestic Abuse, this generates a fantastic response, it is on the Facebook page “Roses are red” also a indie found footage series called “Witches’ Curse” on the haunting of sunshine girl YouTube channel which had many views. You can check out more projects on my own YouTube channel called “Kayleigh Miles.” 
  • We aim to create a realistic approach on the series and draw as many people in, we feel like £500 is enough to get this project up and running. We begin filming around May 15th 2019.

Risks & Challenges

  • Getting this project on the go: We feel like it will be hard at first but once we reach our goal we have the potential to make this happen.
  • We will solve this by coming together and each pitching our own ideas, and getting stuck right into this project. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some may not be able to contribute so here is how you can help us in other ways: 

  • Share the Campaign 
  • Follow our social media accounts @Vampires_theseries on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter. 
  • Share the series after release. 
  • Talk about Vampires the series to people
  • Get a hashtag going #Vampiresseries
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Don’t worry if you cannot contribute, you still can by getting the word out about our series, we Thankyou so much for helping us, stay amazing!

story:
Short Summary

Thank you for taking the time to learn more about this project. The creators realized that no one was creating any content paying homage to 90s. As a result, we have created a series to hoping to inspire, laugh, and revel in a time that was a big influence for our generation. What makes Mary Contrary stand out among other timepieces is the tone of familiarity while magnifying the irony of the 90s culture. Secondly, like you the creators understand that characterization is everything to building great content.  

In the end, we were not only inspired by each other but, also by a period of time that seems like only yesterday. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking you to make our project reality by helping us fund the pilot. If the Pilot is not made then we will refund your money. 

We are hoping to raise 3000 dollars to help fund the actors, equipment, and services for the pilot.

Here's what your contributions will help us cover:

Crew costs

Camera rental

Lights rental

Sound Equipment

Costumes

Location Rental

Food

Production Insurance

Music Licensing

Editing and Post-Production costs

Publicity/Marketing Costs

Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If donating doesn't work for you right now, no worries! You can still support Mary Contrary. A like, comment, retweet, or post can really help us get the word out. 

Thank you so much for joining us on this adventure!

story:
THANK YOU SO MUCH TO ALL OUR BACKERS, OUR INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN IS NOW CLOSED! 

If you'd still like to contribute to us, you are able to do so by donating to secondwavestudios@gmail.com. Or follow us on our socials to keep updated on the project! 

Much love <3

Our production group, Second Wave Studios, was brought together for one reason: we were tired of seeing teen dramas that lacked, or completely failed to do their marginalized/PoC characters justice. Our goal is to bring positive representation to a genre that desperately needs it. That is why we created VISIBLE.

VISIBLE is a standalone teen drama pilot, set in a Toronto working-class immigrant community. It follows a group of passionate but confused teenagers as they navigate their final year of high school and try to rise above the pressures of family, society, and the systems in control.

Set in a working class neighbourhood in Toronto, Sharon, Mustafa and Lee are seniors at Aginview Secondary School. Growing up in immigrant households, they try to navigate their identities and aspirations, all whilst feeling the pressure of high school and their families closing in on them. When someone close to them is targeted and attacked, they decide to seek justice and take on the administration themselves. They soon come to realize that changing the system isn’t as easy as it seems.

Our exec team consists of five fourth-year RTA Media Production students at Ryerson University. Coming together at the beginning of 2019, we’ve been hard at work on pre-production for our first major production.

Carol Liu - Co-Director & Writer

Carol Liu is a Chinese-Canadian visual artist, designer and writer. Born in Shanghai and raised in Toronto, Carol feels a strong connection to the diverse immigrant neighbourhoods of this city. When co-creating the concept for VISIBLE with Maryan, she hoped to accurately portray the experiences of under-represented communities from which they are from.

Maryan Haye - Co-Director & Writer

Maryan Haye is a Somali-Canadian actor and screenwriter from Toronto, Ontario. Growing up in the Jane and Finch community, being in the media industry was never something that she considered an option until she entered university. Co-creating VISIBLE has allowed her to help bring characters similar to the kids she grew up with to life, and she is excited to produce a pilot that brings fresh voices and representation to youth programming.

Levi Linton - Audio & Technical Lead

Levi Linton is an African-Scottish Canadian multifaceted artist born and raised in the upper beaches area of Toronto. Levi experienced so many cultural backgrounds from his childhood community and has always felt one with his ethnic roots. As Audio and Technical Lead, Levi hopes to bring the picture to life with a powerful set of diverse artists in Toronto’s music scene.

Amreen Kullar - Creative Lead

Amreen Kullar is a second gen Indian-Canadian filmmaker and graphic designer. Through her numerous short film productions, surrounding social justice, while featuring commentary on the current digital age, she strives to create tolerance and understanding. She has always been drawn to the visuals of the content she watches and produces, hence, cinematography and art direction is where she is happiest. VISIBLE will allow her to continue creating necessary content to address overlooked stories that struggle to reach mainstream audiences.

Philip LeMoyne - Director of Photography 

Philip is a Montrealer studying in Toronto, going into his second year of Media Production at Ryerson. With experience spanning a vast array of genres, including drama, action, horror, and documentary, Philip has been working in this domain for over two years. He is tasked with creating the imagery for the co-directors’ vision, committing to screen this story of teenage life in Toronto's constantly evolving multicultural society.

 

By helping contribute to this project, you are essentially breathing life into our story and characters. To create the professional, impactful, and relatable pilot that we have envisioned, each member of Second Wave Studios has contributed as much as possible from our own pockets. 

Our fundraising goal of $11,000 will help with the costs of locations, equipment, transportation, insurance, food, and set design so we can create a safe and comfortable creative environment for everybody involved on set!

To show our appreciation for your support, we are offering rewards at different price points - including social-media shout outs, your name in our credits, tickets to our premiere, and even custom creative work by our team members! 

Each contribution is essential to transforming this project into reality, no matter how small the sum!
story_txt: THANK YOU SO MUCH TO ALL OUR BACKERS, OUR INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN IS NOW CLOSED! If you'd still like to contribute to us, you are able to do so by donating to secondwavestudios@gmail.com. Or follow us on our socials to keep updated on the project! Much love <3Our production group, Second Wave Studios, was brought together for one reason: we were tired of seeing teen dramas that lacked, or completely failed to do their marginalized/PoC characters justice. Our goal is to bring positive representation to a genre that desperately needs it. That is why we created VISIBLE.VISIBLE is a standalone teen drama pilot, set in a Toronto working-class immigrant community. It follows a group of passionate but confused teenagers as they navigate their final year of high school and try to rise above the pressures of family, society, and the systems in control.Set in a working class neighbourhood in Toronto, Sharon, Mustafa and Lee are seniors at Aginview Secondary School. Growing up in immigrant households, they try to navigate their identities and aspirations, all whilst feeling the pressure of high school and their families closing in on them. When someone close to them is targeted and attacked, they decide to seek justice and take on the administration themselves. They soon come to realize that changing the system isn’t as easy as it seems.Our exec team consists of five fourth-year RTA Media Production students at Ryerson University. Coming together at the beginning of 2019, we’ve been hard at work on pre-production for our first major production.Carol Liu - Co-Director & WriterCarol Liu is a Chinese-Canadian visual artist, designer and writer. Born in Shanghai and raised in Toronto, Carol feels a strong connection to the diverse immigrant neighbourhoods of this city. When co-creating the concept for VISIBLE with Maryan, she hoped to accurately portray the experiences of under-represented communities from which they are from.Maryan Haye - Co-Director & WriterMaryan Haye is a Somali-Canadian actor and screenwriter from Toronto, Ontario. Growing up in the Jane and Finch community, being in the media industry was never something that she considered an option until she entered university. Co-creating VISIBLE has allowed her to help bring characters similar to the kids she grew up with to life, and she is excited to produce a pilot that brings fresh voices and representation to youth programming.Levi Linton - Audio & Technical LeadLevi Linton is an African-Scottish Canadian multifaceted artist born and raised in the upper beaches area of Toronto. Levi experienced so many cultural backgrounds from his childhood community and has always felt one with his ethnic roots. As Audio and Technical Lead, Levi hopes to bring the picture to life with a powerful set of diverse artists in Toronto’s music scene.Amreen Kullar - Creative LeadAmreen Kullar is a second gen Indian-Canadian filmmaker and graphic designer. Through her numerous short film productions, surrounding social justice, while featuring commentary on the current digital age, she strives to create tolerance and understanding. She has always been drawn to the visuals of the content she watches and produces, hence, cinematography and art direction is where she is happiest. VISIBLE will allow her to continue creating necessary content to address overlooked stories that struggle to reach mainstream audiences.Philip LeMoyne - Director of Photography Philip is a Montrealer studying in Toronto, going into his second year of Media Production at Ryerson. With experience spanning a vast array of genres, including drama, action, horror, and documentary, Philip has been working in this domain for over two years. He is tasked with creating the imagery for the co-directors’ vision, committing to screen this story of teenage life in Toronto's constantly evolving multicultural society. By helping contribute to this project, you are essentially breathing life into our story and characters. To create the professional, impactful, and relatable pilot that we have envisioned, each member of Second Wave Studios has contributed as much as possible from our own pockets. Our fundraising goal of $11,000 will help with the costs of locations, equipment, transportation, insurance, food, and set design so we can create a safe and comfortable creative environment for everybody involved on set!To show our appreciation for your support, we are offering rewards at different price points - including social-media shout outs, your name in our credits, tickets to our premiere, and even custom creative work by our team members! Each contribution is essential to transforming this project into reality, no matter how small the sum!

story:
Who Are We

  • About the Founder: Kamau “Maui” Jones is a director, actor, facilitator, community organizer, and activist. He is also the founder and artistic director of Echo Theater Collective. He has worked on stage and in film, hosted karaoke, run a trivia league, and hosted/created his own game show. In his 30’s he decided to pursue his dream of starting a community theater company. With Echo Theater Collective he has partnered with Suburban Unity Alliance and Oak Park Women of Color and other organizations to curate events focused on giving voices to those less heard such as the Sing! Series (community singalongs to celebrate underrepresented groups), The Minority Monologues (an exploration of cultural identity in America), and The Unity Festival. After realizing the transformative power of sharing our stories, Maui committed himself to social change through art, music, and storytelling. Directorial Credits include: James Baldwin’s Blues for Mister Charlie (2018), Fiddler on the Roof (2016), and Legends of Broadway(2016).

 

  • About Reflect Media: Reflect Media is an intersectional production company for learning how to navigate social emotional space, teaching communities to reclaim their narrative and give them platforms, and give them platforms to be seen and heard. By giving to this campaign you will be helping us create a revolutionary media platform that celebrates the diverse cultures of the near west region. We are a collective of artists with limited funds. The greatest resource we have is you, the community! We hope you can help us fund our inaugural season of production which will lead to important conversations in our community.

What We Need

  • We are looking to raise at least 50,000 dollars to fund our first season of production. The vast majority ($40,000) of that will go to our Puppet/live action show, Ella, the remainder will as fund our podcast network (Conscious Culture, The Dope, and The Echolove Journey) and our local election coverage next year for the near west side. We are planning to facilitate virtual interviews, debates, and town halls!
  • For your contributions (see tiers for more info),  you will be able to get early access to Ella content (music, and exclusive book release based on the pilot episode, and an exclusive reflect t-shirt)
  • If we do not reach our goal the number one priority is producing the first season of Ella.

 

The Lineup

  • About Reflect: An intersectional production company for learning how to navigate social emotional space, teaching communities to reclaim their narrative and give them platforms, and give them platforms to be seen and heard.
  • About Conscious Culture: In this new podcast we discuss stories, news and politics from west side Chicago and suburbs and reflect on the state of our world.
  • About The Dope: In this new podcast our diverse panel of hosts discuss everything in pop culture from literature and music, to everyone’s favorite shows and movies and examine how pop culture reflects our everyday lives.
  • About The Echolove Journey: In this new podcast, join Maui as he chronicles his journey of learning how to live intentionally after a near death experience and seeks out other people on transformative journeys
  • About Ella: Half hour program for SEL messaging. Ella is a 4 year old biracial girl whose father watches her and the neighborhood children. Every show some of Ella’s friends come over and have discussions and activities together.
  •  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute monetarily, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Regardless of whether or not you can give, please help us by spreading the word! Help us make some noise! Remember that Indiegogo has plenty of share tools!

Thank YOU!

The Reflect Team

story:
We can't express how much it means to us that you're visiting our campaign page.  Here's a little welcome film from the creator and the producer of Platonic Season 2!
 

Thank You and Welcome!

 
 

What started as a fun side project for a group of actors and filmmaker friends became a full-on web series with a dedicated, enthusiastic, and incredibly wonderful fan following.  The first season premiered in July of 2014, and since then we get the question, "When are you going to make more 'Platonic?!'" almost every single day.  So, nearly three years to the day of wrapping season one, we filmed the first episode of season 2 for this Indiegogo campaign!

The careers of many involved in Platonic have soared since the first season, and we can't wait to have the full cast and crew back for more!

 

 

$150,000 sounds like a lotta money.  And it is.  To a project like ours, however, it's the minimum amount we've come up with to cover all of our expenses in making Platonic Season 2.  When it's completed, Platonic Season 2 will be close to the length of a shorter feature film.  Budgets for features can range anywhere from $5 million to $250 million without breaking a sweat.  That said, our budget will include stretch goals in the event that we manage to exceed our campaign number, and we hope we do!  Below is a (not exactly to scale) graph of what the distribution of funds will look like:

(Artist's rendering ;)

 

So many things to get and have!

Here's an easy-to-read layout of all the lovely perks of being a contributor to Platonic Season 2:

 

A show like Platonic is pure entertainment and enjoyment.  We receive notes and messages all the time from a diverse array of people telling us how much they enjoy being able to unwind to our show and how they can't wait to sit down to another season.  We love that viewers all over the world can laugh and (almost) cry with the crazy characters of Platonic.

Bringing back a second season of the show will provide months of work to our crew as well as consistent and highly coveted acting work for our amazing and talented actors. 

And if that isn't enough, just consider the impact your gift could make to one member of our crew...

"Be The Change"
 

We realize that we have a lot of fans out there who may not have the means to contribute right now, and we want you to know how much you are loved simply for watching the show!  And supporting Platonic goes so far beyond mere money.  If you want to get involved in other ways, here's what you can do:

  • Follow our Instagram and Twitter pages (@platonicseries) and share everything you can! 
  • Like our Facebook page www.facebook.com/platonicseries
  • Tell your friends about the show and watch the first season with them at www.funnyordie.com/platonic
  • Just keep being amazing.

Thank you, everyone, for your support and love!

story:
Punch-lining Homophobia

Funny matters. Gay visibility matters. Let's do both.

  • People get fatigued by political messaging.
  • Humans are tribalist. Defenses are up.
  • We're all disarmed when laughing together.

 

Fundraising for 2 Initial Videos

Gay-splainer satirically pokes fun at people who treat the queer community like make-over machines and sassy side-kicks. (runtime: 6 minutes)

Avenue WTF absurdly depicts a counseling session for a man and his hand, literally exploring gay self love. (runtime: 8 minutes)

Sketches are based on serious, real life experiences, and presented with a laugh-first POV.
 

We're Ahead of the Game

Both sketches were just fully rehearsed and presented live at the People's Improv Theater in May of 2018. We're ready to film right now!

 

A UNIQUE STORY: Comedy Nerd Trapped in Dancer's Body

After being an outcast in both the crunchy modern dance landscape and creamy commercial dance scene, it's clear I've been miscast in my own life.

Now that I've indulged in comedy writing and improv classes, I've got a new language to vomit out the funny that's backed up in my system.

Bored with the pretense of hot moves and high art, I'm embracing what I truly am- a comedy spaz.

 

Donate Because...

-Pride season.

-You also want something different from your life.

-There aren't enough funny gays telling their stories in the public eye.

-I'm one of the nicest (most talented) people you know, and I deserve a break.

-You feel guilty for not coming to my live shows. Yeah, I see you.

 

Be Selfish. Contribute For the Perks

-Shameless Acknowledgement of your generous spirit (under $25)

-Ally Status ($25)

-Raunchy Ringtones ($50)

-Resume Booster ($75)

-Immortality in film ($100)

-Happiness (dopamine, serotonin, and oxytocin will flood your body upon donating)

 

Renting People, Places, and Things

PEOPLE ($2000): We're paying from $150-$500, based on level of involvement, though it cold be more. That includes the main cast, directors, camera pro, graphics specialist, and a film editor.

PLACES ($1500): We'll be shooting on a couple sound stages at DCTV in downtown Manhattan during July and August of 2018.

THINGS ($1500): DCTV has given us a deal on a FS700 camera package that includes a shotgun mic on a boom pole with mixer. We've also reserved two Tungston lighting packages, with additional LED options and gel combos.

This all quickly equals $5000 and could easily be more. It's a scrappy operation but we're hell-bent on up-ing our production value and paying creatives for their talent.

 

With Little Effort on Your Part, You Can...

  • Turn this one-man-band into an army of funny, smart people that need you to laugh more.
  • Use comedy as a common denominator for diverse audiences to empathize with each other.
  • Use video to create new access points for audiences to experience gay people.
  • Be credited as a creative and round out that resume of yours.

 

You're Investing in a "Type A" Gay That Makes Stuff Happen

Through utter nerdmanship and sheer force of will, I've managed, with no money or pedigree, to...

-Get featured by major publications.

-Receive residencies and commissions from arts organizations.

-Be accepted into international film festivals.

Imagine what I can do with even a little bit of your money?

 

Confronting Possible Objections

Jamie, people have different senses of humor. We attack this like Saturday Night Live does.

  • Gay-splainer is of the Harvard, smarty-pants style of humor.
  • Avenue WTF is all absurdist, low-brow jokes.

People may not need this to be an extended series.

  • We won't know until we try a few. And if the people want more, we'll begin a Patreon account for continuous support.

I'm a creative type that doesn't have any money.

  • So am I. But, having been a fundraiser for a bunch of arts-based non-profits, I know the art world runs on funding from people just like us. You matter here and we love you for it.

 

Need for Comedy Greater Than Ever?

  • Stephen Colbert had most late night viewers last year.
  • SNL's 42nd season was the highest watched in 23 years.
  • Samantha Bee's ratings jumped 175%, post 2016 election.

These stats (CNN) show that more people are turning to comedy to "cope with their angst over the new administration." (Stephen Battaglio, LA Times)

Let's help people emotionally deal with the divisive and deeply upsetting issues of the day.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with friends, family, the comically inclined, or anyone that looks like they need a good laugh.

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

With Warmth and Queer Affection,

Jamie Benson
