story:
Short Summary

All of This Is Yours provides young audiences with the educational tools they need to begin creating the world they want to live in as global citizens through an episodic journey filled with unique cultural experiences and practical lessons that children can use in their everyday lives. The campaign will raise money for a pilot episode which will take Robin to San Jose Costa Rica where she will meet Amanda, a young girl ready to share her life, and her extended family, with the world.

Robin Hancock has been an avid traveler all her life. While working on a doctorate in education, she got the idea to create a series that blended her love for travel with her passion for early childhood ed. Her life's work examines the ways that identifying as a global citizen can empower children to walk in the world with confidence, pride in their communities and awareness of their positions as members of a large and vibrant global community. 

This is Robin's passion project and her heart's desire for the last ten years has been to make this series a reality. Your contribution to the creation of the pilot episode will contribute to a field desperately in need of new and exciting voices. No gift is too small (or too big)!!

What We Need 

We are looking to raise $13,000.00.

Production

Airfare- $1800 (writer/host/producer, director, sound)

Equipment insurance and shipping- $700

3 nights hotel accommodations-  $700

Transportation within Costa Rica (car/cab) - $600

Meals - $450 

Participant compensation - $500

Crew compensation- $3,600

- Director/Videographer: $1,200 (3 days)

- Sound: $1,200 (3 days)

- Writer/host/Producer: $1,200 (3 days)

Post Production- 

Editing and Consultation: $2,000 

Color: $500

Sound mixing: $500

Festival, workshop and pitch submission and attendance: $500

Additional cost- $1150

The Impact

Nowhere on television is there a travel series that is  1) hosted by a woman of color 2) geared towards educating children and 3) focused on teaching global citizenship. The travel genre remains a deeply segregated space and very few series in the genre are created intentionally for children. This series will counter the negative messages of division and hyper-nationalism that are so prevalent in our society. Our goals for the series are to:

- Provide the (near absent) representation of central characters of color in the travel show genre.

- Provide a travel series that is geared towards young children in a genre that is tailored almost exclusively to adults.

- Create an educational platform for children to learn about the world through observing the experiences of other children like them who live in and negotiate that world as well.

- Create a context where children are learning the primary tenets of Global Citizenship early in life.

- Challenge the messages of separation and division currently being taught through our government, media and social spaces.

Ways You Can Help

DONATE!!!!

Please make a LOT of noise about this project. You can do that in a number of ways:

Post this on all of your social media pages

Circulate it to ALL of your friends and social networks

share in your frequently visited spaces

Stand on corners and knock on doors (just kidding...kind of...)

The Impact

Nowhere on television is there a travel series that is  1) hosted by a woman of color 2) geared towards educating children and 3) focused on teaching global citizenship. The travel genre remains a deeply segregated space and very few series in the genre are created intentionally for children. This series will counter the negative messages of division and hyper-nationalism that are so prevalent in our society. Our goals for the series are to:
- Provide the (near absent) representation of central characters of color in the travel show genre.
- Provide a travel series that is geared towards young children in a genre that is tailored almost exclusively to adults.
- Create an educational platform for children to learn about the world through observing the experiences of other children like them who live in and negotiate that world as well.
- Create a context where children are learning the primary tenets of Global Citizenship early in life.
- Challenge the messages of separation and division currently being taught through our government, media and social spaces.

Ways You Can Help
DONATE!!!!

Please make a LOT of noise about this project. You can do that in a number of ways:
Post this on all of your social media pages
Circulate it to ALL of your friends and social networks
share in your frequently visited spaces
Stand on corners and knock on doors (just kidding...kind of...)

story:
THE SERIES

Journey to Mictlan, a brand-new fantasy , is an eight-episode limited 5-10-minute web series that follows, Mexican American teen Mia Ortega who is haunted by the deaths of her Mother Maria Ortega, and Sister Sofia Ortega after a terrible accident while cliff diving. Wrought with pain and a need to have her family back she seeks out the help of a consultant to the dead named Reina, a woman with a secret who resembles Mia’s mother. Reina sets Mia off on an impossible voyage to bring her family back from the dead before the end of the third day of Día de Muertos, only for Mia to end up on an ever-endless journey to a whole other world… a journey to the Aztec underworld Mictlan.

ALL ABOUT THE CREATOR

The series was created and will also be directed by , Yessania Cheyenne who also produced and wrote Rooftop Sentiments a short film that was chosen for official selection at the International Monarch Film Festival in 2015, and runner up in the Latino Film Market in 2017.  She finished a Bachelor's Degree in Film from Brooklyn College in 2017.  She also attended both Savannah College of Art & Design  from 2007-2009, and New York Film Academy in 2014.  

From the Creator:

"In 2005 when I was seventeen years of age I lost my mother who I was close to. And  in 2016 I lost my grandmother who I was also very close to.  Losing two strong  independent women who were both my inspiration and support  for the filmmaker I turned out to be today, I needed an outlet  to let go of my sadness and my grief and so I wrote; wrote about a family who was also very close, and loses each other but unlike me has the opportunity to find each other again. At the time of my mother's death  I started off on a  journey to learn more about my Mexican  heritage.  So by creating this story I come  a little bit further to learniing about who I am as a person. It has allowed me to appreciate both my African American and Mexican American Heritage."

What We Need

The development and preproduction of Journey to Mictlan has been officially completed and will be filmed on location in  New York  under a two week production schedule  at the end of August - September. 

The web series will star an all women cast of four upcoming Latina actresses for the roles of the lead characters: Mia Ortega and Reina; and supporting characters: Carmilia and Sofia Ortega. The character role of Mia’s mother Maria Ortega will be played by the same actress as Reina’s character. This series will be both produced in Spanish and English.

To produce the web series, we will need  a little more help with  raising  funds of $16,000 for  production cost to pay:

  • The four lovely actresses, Extras &The crew: Co-director, grips, DP​, sound, set designer, makeup artist,editor ($10,000)
  • Location permit cost & Transportation cost  ( which will  only be three sets filmed on location  in  either New York or Atlanta) the three story locations are:  the mountains, a house, and a park ($4,000)
  • Insurance ($1,000)
  • Marketing​ & Distribution cost ($1,000)

We would also be collecting in-kind  donations for the props & wardrobes.

TOTAL = $16,000

What You Get

You will receive these wonderful perks for contributing:

  • A special personalized  thank you message on both Twitter and YouTube 
  • A digital copy of  the signed screenplay  of season 1 by the creator
  • Digital behind the scenes footage and virtual gear  

Featured Perks

  • You will get a special thanks credit at the end of one of the eight episodes. There are only 80 of these perks.
  • Your name will be mentioned by one of the characters in an episode.There are only 7 of these perks. 

Upper Tier Perks

  • A google meet Q&A with the cast and creator. There are only 10 of these perks. 
  • A day on set. ( for this perk you must be local) There are only 8 of these perks. 
  • Invitation to Lunch and  the premiere  private screening of the complete season 1. There are only 8  of these perks

Where will the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal?

We will use the funds to go towards the production to shoot the  pilot and  two  other episodes.  Every amount counts. We are also actively seeking other funding from other  fundraising and investors.

The Impact

Your contributions will make a tremendous difference because it will mean one more person can tell there meaningful story in there own voice and it will help allow  inclusion for minorities both behind and in front of the camera. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand  that not  everyone will be able to contribute . So we ask that you please share this campaign with eveyone you know.  Follow us on Twitter, and subscribe with us on YouTube. 

Thank You  for all of your support.

story:
Purpose

*Did you watch the pilot webisode (rough cut:  pre-final cc/grading, inserts, audio) posted above?*  B-movie magic is what we're aiming for, sorry to the film snobs!  We won't have the legions of advanced ex-machinas, Majors or Nexus 6s, spaceships or huge explosions but we're confident in delivering sheer bodacious entertainment regardless.  The script will deal with familiar and up-coming technologies e.g mixed reality, artificial intelligence, decentralized networks / compute power, blockchain, automation, bio-genetics etc. 

The Show  (www.elegantscum.com)

The story takes place roughly seven to ten years in the future.  Las Vegas Nevada, Sin City is dealing with economic discord, a populous of tinkerers of both old and new tech.  Society is a mosh pit full of usual and unusual suspects; infidels, hackers, criminals, virtual succubus, real high-tech  low lives fighting societal displacement due in part by today's industrial renaissance, AI and automation.  The story has a heavy emphasis on virtual reality and its potential impediments on real world populous and the defilement of human productivity in the physical world. Characters often showcase Freudian slips, pitted against their own demons so to speak as the show's slogan itself explains how  .... "VR is the Devil's new playground..."

Director | writer JSK and team definitely draw heavy influence from classic cyberpunk vanguards but also have developed the project's own unique look and feel to add to the sub genre.   (visit www.elegantscum.com for more on the cast and project elements!)

The Team in progress 

  Our team is a mashup within itself.  Directors, writers, cinematographers, thespians, grip, lights, sound design, beer runners, bar flies, alt coin traders, musicians, software devs you name it!  Core team:  Eli Oberlander, John Robinson, Tony Capil, James Wilhelm, Sam Elbaz, Jesse S Koda, Matt Heck, George Gardner.  

Funding

*Check out the image gallery above for some of the perks!

Full $28,000 allocation for producing the remaining seven (7) webisodes + revisions for pilot.  (We have most of webisode two filmed already!).  Low budget but we'll make it work!

  • $5,500 equipment upgrades: We've filmed with a combination of Sony FS5, RED Raven and Panasonic GH4.  For those that understand video production, it is kind of a pain in the ____ to match up footage recorded from different cameras. With proper funding we would switch over to full RED or Black Magic setups, purchasing camera bodies and sound equipment but renting lenses, lights and rigs other accessories.
  • $4,000+ insurance, permits, locations 
  • $8,000 Priority of resources will be applied towards wardrobe, props, set design and post production.   Sound mixing, proper color/grading and of course VFX to help boost our production value and creative sandbox!  Although our crew has been very creative and efficient with costs, practical effects can run a tab and same goes with sourcing high-quality VFX talent.  We also plan to get some really good indie electro-industrial artists to help score.
  • $2200-2500 goes to IndieGoGo fees and perks.
  • $1,500 towards some fundamental marketing material; we plan to have artists and designers like NYC's Ariel ZB (who did our beautiful poster art) create some comic style storyboarding and additional artwork!  
  • est. $6,500 goes toward feeding and providing some minimal pay for our very talented local cast and crew for what will easily be over 1+ full days of production.  That's about a total of $350-$375 per 8 hour day of filming including both cast/crew.  We pretty much work for shake-shack & beer !

The Impact

The support would help enhance our micro-budget project several fold by expanding our production sandbox, post production quality and quite frankly, some rations for our cast/crew!  We are resourceful and viciously dedicated to not wasting a dime outside of production.  We want to create a indie staple not just in the sub-genre of cyberpunk but something that can be enjoyed and shared by all science fiction fans.  

Risks & Challenges

For those that understand, like any creative endeavor there are always challenges in it's finality, meeting expectations etc.  But we are going about this project very pragmatically from the jump and are again fully committed to completing this mini series for the world to enjoy (or roast...)

  • Finishing eight entire episodes.  As you see, we have posted our initial webisode (pilot) and are ready to continue production to finish the series.  But the challenge is again, in budgets.
  • With your support we can ensure progress continues!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please help share and spread this campaign for fellow enthusiasts that would be interested in supporting and watching such a series come to fruition.
  • Contact us with any ideas or suggestions, we're more than happy to listen!
  • The Indiegogo share tools are a great start!

Thank you for taking the time to review our campaign and we hope you will consider supporting the project!  - Team Velvet Crux

For those that understand, like any creative endeavor there are always challenges in it's finality, meeting expectations etc.  But we are going about this project very pragmatically from the jump and are again fully committed to completing this mini series for the world to enjoy (or roast...)

Finishing eight entire episodes.  As you see, we have posted our initial webisode (pilot) and are ready to continue production to finish the series.  But the challenge is again, in budgets.
With your support we can ensure progress continues!

 

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please help share and spread this campaign for fellow enthusiasts that would be interested in supporting and watching such a series come to fruition.
Contact us with any ideas or suggestions, we're more than happy to listen!
The Indiegogo share tools are a great start!

Thank you for taking the time to review our campaign and we hope you will consider supporting the project!  - Team Velvet Crux

story:
The Creator

Matt Harsh is a filmmaker from Champaign-Urbana  IL. He started filming local bands and events and progressed to writing and directing music videos for some of those awesome bands.
Check out some videos here: http://mattharsh.wordpress.com/music-videos/

The Idea
Wolfbear began as a joke between two friends. It is a nickname for the director, Matt Harsh. This quickly escalated to Facebook posts and Photoshopped images. The Photoshopped pictures became popular among friends and led to the creation of a Facebook page. Check out Wolfbear's web page: http://theadventuresofwolfbear.wordpress.com/

or "like" him on Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/pages/WolfBear/2718129...


Wolfbear has gained fans of all kinds.  People in Chicago,Berlin,  NY, California, moms, and even Won a local award for best CU Personality . This popularity encouraged Matt to expand on the fun and start writing a Narrated-Photo Collage-style show about Wolfbear's History and his journey to find Civilization - His Journey landing him at a Truck Stop along the Highway. Meeting all sorts of special characters along the way   

Season 1 will be all about that.

Wolfbear makes some great allies but he also finds some people who don't like how different he is. He struggles to control his instincts (like chasing and eating animals) while trying to find his place in this new world.
---
Wolfbear is silly and fun, and also offers a bit of deeper thought on the idea of humanity, dreams, and how we see and judge each other---it also might  be funny!

What will the money go to?

This campaign is designed to help cover some basic needs, but most importantly get people aware and to feel apart of it.
PLUS T-SHIRTS!!!!!

We are offering some cool incentives like , screen-printed posters & t-shirts, as well as advance viewing of episodes, premiere party,, and even cameos in the show.
Everyone gets a thank you

No money, but wanna help?

If you can't contribute money, but would like to contribute your Music or Photos - 

harshpro.video@gmail.com 

-----

Please share this with your friends and family and help us raise some cash for a fun project.

Thank you!

story:
The Road Here

Hey there. I'm Alyssa... a shy little Ravenclaw who is tremendously bombastic once you get to know me. Promise.

I am the creator and one of the Executive Producers of an apocalyptic-comedy web series called Total Party Kill, about a group of RPG players that livestream the first night of the apocalypse and then find themselves fighting for survival from the confines of a military-enforced quarantine.

My team and I are raising the money needed to finish shooting our first season.

TPK is a hell of a lot of fun (pun intended): there's action, adventure, romance, comedy, drama... it is fantastical while being grounded in human relationship and emotion. It's everything I've been striving to make since I left the walls of the little art college I attended in Philly and trekked out to the sunny streets of LA.

I'm openly queer, identifying as pansexual (and sort of dress like a 13-year-old kid in a snapback, ripped jeans, high tops, and a mix of leather jackets, plaid, and bomber coats. Man, I miss the 90s). I'm also a huge, I mean, HUGE, fangirl.

Exhibit A:

--Ravenclaw snapback. The nerdiest nerd to ever nerd. 

Fanfic? I write it.
My first spec script was for an episode of Buffy the Vampire Slayer. No, sorry, you can't read it - not because it was terrible (it was, I was like 14) but because I no longer have it (RIP Buffy episode).

I play RPGs. On a livestream. And I adore it.

Basically I wanted to make a show that combined all these things into one cheeky amalgamation of apocalyptic tumult. And thus, here we are, looking to raise the funds needed to finish the first season of TPK. 

You can watch the first four episodes below or head over to our YouTube Channel (and subscribe while you're there!) to see.

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise $15,000. Where will that go?

  • Actors and crew.
  • Equipment, location, and insurance fees.
  • Props, costumes, and make-up.
  • Post production.
  • Food. (CRAFTY IS SO IMPORTANT, FRIENDS)

Look, a handy chart!

PERKS

  • Social media follows and shout-outs. We love being active with our followers and contributors! Virtual, consensual hugs for all.
  • Digital copy of the script of an episode of your choice [once we've aired the season, of course. No spoilers! ;)]
  • Video shout out done by some of the cast, shot during our days of shooting.
  • BTS package: interviews and other behind-the-scenes fun. And of course bloopers. Or as we call them, bloobs.
  • Get a reference sneaked in - got a nerdy little shout out you want to see or hear? I'll make it happen.
  • Digital copy of each in-game character within the campaign in TPK.
  • Digital copy of a character sheet tailored to you (or anyone you'd like)!
  • Contributing Producer credit.

Keep an eye out for our updates, because we also have interviews on the way and special offers for you as we hit certain benchmarks in the campaign! What are these? Well, they're surprises. You'll have to wait and see...

But, Alyssa, what happens if you don't raise all the money you need?

My team and I are dedicated filmmakers and the majority of us work full-time in television and film production while producing our own work on the side. We love finding creative solutions.

Any money we do raise will go toward making this series a reality, even if part of that becomes taking the money raised and creating the best thing we can on a tighter than anticipated budget. We have creative gears churning all the time and are dedicated to bringing this show to you, at its best, in any way possible!

Meet the Cast:

Alyssa Appleton - "Kat Kaplan"
Alyssa Ariel Perez - "SFC Desiree Winter"
Jennifer Karraz - "Jamie Barton"
Sascha Vanderslik - "Stef Lennox"
Kyle Marie Colucci - "Lacie Brooks"
Chris McGahan - "Chase Ahearn"
Quinn Knox - "Brandon Rae"

Read bios and find out more about them HERE!

The Impact

I could talk all day about how much this project means to me and how much it means that you're even here, scrolling down and reading these words. 

I am a tempest of emotion. And those of you that know me, know how much I love tempestuous things.

TPK is queer positive and body positive, not only in front of the camera but behind it as well.

When was the first time you saw yourself represented in the media - whether a film or a show or a commercial, maybe a song... anywhere? Did it bring you a sense of peace? Of feeling seen and understood? Did it connect you to that character in a way you never felt before, and connect you with others that were a fan of that piece of entertainment? Representation matters, it can help us feel like someone out there understands us, like there are people like us, like we're a part of something.

Kat's a curvier character - and she gets to lead the charge, get the girl, and be a (flawed) hero while being curvy, queer, and kicking butt. Jamie gets to be nerdy and brainy and is celebrated for it. Stef and Lacie have the chance to play out the triumphs and tribulations of a long-term relationship in the midst of chaos and gloom and doom. Desiree is a soldier with a warm heart, an openness to this group of people she's known for a short amount of time - and she and Kat get to share some intimacies, fears, joys, and terrors. Brandon proves introverts have real, true power when faced with adversity. And Chase gets to show us all that even if you're a bit of a goof-ball, you can rise up to help save your friends when you need to.

Our wonderful cast (a bit bloodied but no less stellar for it):

Risks & Challenges

We're a small group. Making the first four episodes was challenging in itself: we had a miniscule budget, had a single day of rehearsal and one of shooting, and even lost some of our footage in a tech fluke. 

But we came out with four episodes I'm proud of, three of which you can enjoy RIGHT NOW, episodes that have had positive response at film festivals and online this year.

I work full-time in television production, even when I'm producing my own stuff on the side. I see the struggles big studios face on the daily, and the ways we have to course-correct to face them creatively. 

An actor suddenly becomes unavailable? The budget gets tightened? You lose footage?

We found ways of making the fluke in our fourth episode work. In fact, what we used to solve it became one of my favorite additions in the episodes: the glitches.

When things don't go as planned it can be stressful, but meeting it head-on and seeing it as an opportunity to make something better can open up a whole new world within the production. I value this outlook in my team.

Other Ways You Can Help

I've only recently been lucky enough to be in a financial place to put money aside each year in order to contribute toward the works of underrepresented filmmakers, but I know how tight money can be.

What else can you do besides or in addition to contributing?

SIGNAL BOOST.

The internet is a stunning tool when used for good - after all, with great power comes great responsibility.

If you happen to be in any fandom on the planet, you know how incredible the internet can be. It connects people all around the world, it has made whole careers for artists and creators. Your shares and follows are integral to us getting the word out about our lil end of days tale.

Twitter: @tpk_series
Instagram: @totalpartykillseries
YouTube: Total Party Kill

Thank you for your support. All the consensual hugs for you.

We'll see you at the apocalypse.
story_txt:
The Road Here
Hey there. I'm Alyssa... a shy little Ravenclaw who is tremendously bombastic once you get to know me. Promise.
I am the creator and one of the Executive Producers of an apocalyptic-comedy web series called Total Party Kill, about a group of RPG players that livestream the first night of the apocalypse and then find themselves fighting for survival from the confines of a military-enforced quarantine.
My team and I are raising the money needed to finish shooting our first season.
TPK is a hell of a lot of fun (pun intended): there's action, adventure, romance, comedy, drama... it is fantastical while being grounded in human relationship and emotion. It's everything I've been striving to make since I left the walls of the little art college I attended in Philly and trekked out to the sunny streets of LA.
I'm openly queer, identifying as pansexual (and sort of dress like a 13-year-old kid in a snapback, ripped jeans, high tops, and a mix of leather jackets, plaid, and bomber coats. Man, I miss the 90s). I'm also a huge, I mean, HUGE, fangirl.
Exhibit A:

--Ravenclaw snapback. The nerdiest nerd to ever nerd. 
Fanfic? I write it.My first spec script was for an episode of Buffy the Vampire Slayer. No, sorry, you can't read it - not because it was terrible (it was, I was like 14) but because I no longer have it (RIP Buffy episode).
I play RPGs. On a livestream. And I adore it.
Basically I wanted to make a show that combined all these things into one cheeky amalgamation of apocalyptic tumult. And thus, here we are, looking to raise the funds needed to finish the first season of TPK. 
You can watch the first four episodes below or head over to our YouTube Channel (and subscribe while you're there!) to see.

What We Need & What You Get
We're looking to raise $15,000. Where will that go?

Actors and crew.
Equipment, location, and insurance fees.
Props, costumes, and make-up.
Post production.
Food. (CRAFTY IS SO IMPORTANT, FRIENDS)

Look, a handy chart!

PERKS

Social media follows and shout-outs. We love being active with our followers and contributors! Virtual, consensual hugs for all.
Digital copy of the script of an episode of your choice [once we've aired the season, of course. No spoilers! ;)]
Video shout out done by some of the cast, shot during our days of shooting.
BTS package: interviews and other behind-the-scenes fun. And of course bloopers. Or as we call them, bloobs.
Get a reference sneaked in - got a nerdy little shout out you want to see or hear? I'll make it happen.
Digital copy of each in-game character within the campaign in TPK.
Digital copy of a character sheet tailored to you (or anyone you'd like)!
Contributing Producer credit.

Keep an eye out for our updates, because we also have interviews on the way and special offers for you as we hit certain benchmarks in the campaign! What are these? Well, they're surprises. You'll have to wait and see...
But, Alyssa, what happens if you don't raise all the money you need?
My team and I are dedicated filmmakers and the majority of us work full-time in television and film production while producing our own work on the side. We love finding creative solutions.
Any money we do raise will go toward making this series a reality, even if part of that becomes taking the money raised and creating the best thing we can on a tighter than anticipated budget. We have creative gears churning all the time and are dedicated to bringing this show to you, at its best, in any way possible!

Meet the Cast:
Alyssa Appleton - "Kat Kaplan"Alyssa Ariel Perez - "SFC Desiree Winter"Jennifer Karraz - "Jamie Barton"Sascha Vanderslik - "Stef Lennox"Kyle Marie Colucci - "Lacie Brooks"Chris McGahan - "Chase Ahearn"Quinn Knox - "Brandon Rae"
Read bios and find out more about them HERE!
The Impact
I could talk all day about how much this project means to me and how much it means that you're even here, scrolling down and reading these words. 
I am a tempest of emotion. And those of you that know me, know how much I love tempestuous things.
TPK is queer positive and body positive, not only in front of the camera but behind it as well.
When was the first time you saw yourself represented in the media - whether a film or a show or a commercial, maybe a song... anywhere? Did it bring you a sense of peace? Of feeling seen and understood? Did it connect you to that character in a way you never felt before, and connect you with others that were a fan of that piece of entertainment? Representation matters, it can help us feel like someone out there understands us, like there are people like us, like we're a part of something.
Kat's a curvier character - and she gets to lead the charge, get the girl, and be a (flawed) hero while being curvy, queer, and kicking butt. Jamie gets to be nerdy and brainy and is celebrated for it. Stef and Lacie have the chance to play out the triumphs and tribulations of a long-term relationship in the midst of chaos and gloom and doom. Desiree is a soldier with a warm heart, an openness to this group of people she's known for a short amount of time - and she and Kat get to share some intimacies, fears, joys, and terrors. Brandon proves introverts have real, true power when faced with adversity. And Chase gets to show us all that even if you're a bit of a goof-ball, you can rise up to help save your friends when you need to.
Our wonderful cast (a bit bloodied but no less stellar for it):


Risks & Challenges
We're a small group. Making the first four episodes was challenging in itself: we had a miniscule budget, had a single day of rehearsal and one of shooting, and even lost some of our footage in a tech fluke. 
But we came out with four episodes I'm proud of, three of which you can enjoy RIGHT NOW, episodes that have had positive response at film festivals and online this year.
I work full-time in television production, even when I'm producing my own stuff on the side. I see the struggles big studios face on the daily, and the ways we have to course-correct to face them creatively. 
An actor suddenly becomes unavailable? The budget gets tightened? You lose footage?
We found ways of making the fluke in our fourth episode work. In fact, what we used to solve it became one of my favorite additions in the episodes: the glitches.
When things don't go as planned it can be stressful, but meeting it head-on and seeing it as an opportunity to make something better can open up a whole new world within the production. I value this outlook in my team.

Other Ways You Can Help
I've only recently been lucky enough to be in a financial place to put money aside each year in order to contribute toward the works of underrepresented filmmakers, but I know how tight money can be.
What else can you do besides or in addition to contributing?
SIGNAL BOOST.
The internet is a stunning tool when used for good - after all, with great power comes great responsibility.
If you happen to be in any fandom on the planet, you know how incredible the internet can be. It connects people all around the world, it has made whole careers for artists and creators. Your shares and follows are integral to us getting the word out about our lil end of days tale.
Twitter: @tpk_seriesInstagram: @totalpartykillseriesYouTube: Total Party Kill
Thank you for your support. All the consensual hugs for you.
We'll see you at the apocalypse.

story:
Brennan & Victoria Make Rent follows best friends and roommates as they do just about anything to stay in the city of Toronto. Short on their rent, they work any job and fabricate any scheme they can think of to come up with the money.

The first episode finds them commandeering a ghost tour, they never do anything halfway. You can find them working a coat check, going on dinner dates to cover grocery costs, and turning their apartment into an escape room. Brennan & Victoria Make Rent is a (only slightly) heightened version of the trials and tribulations people go through to afford living in the city.

The series takes place over the course of a few weeks, with their rent due by the end of the month. Over the five episodes Brennan and Victoria are tested as individuals, roommates, and friends.

Brennan & Victoria Make Rent is a 5 episode live-action comedy web-series set in the oh-so expensive city of Toronto, Ontario Canada. We intend to showcase  local comedians as various characters throughout the episodes.

This web series is being produced by Ossington & College Productions, a group of Ryerson media production students completing Brennan & Victoria Make Rent as their 4th year thesis production project. Featuring the always strange but beautiful city of Toronto and a story familiar to most (doing what you can to pay the rent), this web series will hit you with the laughs. 

The scripts were completed in March 2018 and various Toronto locations such as Old Town, Little Italy and Trinity Bellwoods Park have been scouted to bring it to life!

Pre-production began in February 2018. A 229 page production bible was created, complete with storyboards, location plan, audio plan and a comprehensive budget.

This indiegogo campaign has been created to help fund Brennan & Victoria Make Rent. The order is to fund it, film it and distribute it back to you, the audience!

Your donation will go toward craft services, transportation, location permits, wardrobe and set dressing as well as festival submission fees.

Our total budget is $8,059.80. With our “indiegogo goal” reached (try saying that three times fast!) we would in effect be fully funded. If we are fully funded we intend to provide honorariums to musicians and artists that work on the project.

We are making an executive contribution of $3,500.

Our biggest costs are in two categories: 

Transportation: $2,400 including vehicle rentals and fuel

Location: $4,100 including permits to film in the city and meals for cast and crew.

The plan is to shoot the series over 10 days during late September into October. November and December will be focused on editing and marketing the project. All 5 episodes should be available to folks by the end of January 2019!

We want to produce Brennan & Victoria Make Rent so we can make you laugh! Without an audience there is no one to watch the series. This is your formal invite to be our audience. We will post updates on the indiegogo page to keep everyone informed about progress on the series and provide more information about the project as it develops. Check out our perks and donate now to have your hand in this project!

If you are in the Toronto area please consider coming to a comedy show fundraiser we will be holding early fall! Take a cue from Brennan’s character in episode 4 and make your date pay. It is a win win situation as you support the web series but the date shoulders the cost!  

If you can’t contribute financially to this project, we do understand. 2018 be some tight times my friends. Hence the whole plot of the series! Fun fact (but not fun at all) according to a Demographia International Housing Affordability Survey, Toronto is ranked 5th most unaffordable city in the world.  So on that note, at the end of the day, all we can ask for is your support.

We would be grateful if you told your friends and family about the series. Aaaaaand... a little tweet, like or share of our campaign through your social media never hurt!

Brennan & Victoria, Writer & Creators
Brennan Asbridge and Victoria Kucher are each a half that make up the whole that is the improv duo Two Girls One Trench Coat. Brennan and Victoria met almost three years ago while studying in the Second City’s Conservatory program, and they’ve been performing and producing shows together ever since. Together and separately they’ve performed at festivals in Toronto, Edmonton, Vancouver, Pittsburgh, Chicago, and now they hope to perform all over the world via their internet web series. If you don't like the internet, you can also see them live performing on shows all over Toronto, including their monthly show “Seeing Double,” the third Tuesday of every month, 9:30pm at Comedy Bar.

Meaghan Stringer, Director
Meaghan likes to make people laugh. On purpose or by accident is no problem for her. She is Brennan’s real life roommate in Toronto and they are both entering their fourth year in Media Production at Ryerson. Meaghan can’t wait to work with Brennan’s stellar script and showcase the talented comedians she’s seen in the city of Toronto.

Alex Baigent, Audio Lead
Alex is a total audio freak, he doesn’t ever stop talking about it. He is interested in local music communities in Toronto and other cities. Alex is beyond excited to spend the next few months on set listening to planes and streetcars passing by in the distance through his headphones. Furthermore, he is even more excited to attempt editing out those noises in post production software!

Yasmin Lau, Producer
Yasmin took on the challenge of producing for the first time with a bit of uncertainty, but her mind was set after reading the first page of Brennan & Victoria Make Rent. Her love for comedy and acting led her to pursue this hilarious, relatable and heartwarming project.

Kiana Ghaziani, Editor 
Kiana has a passion for video editing. For her, editing raw footage is visual story-telling set apart from the film plot. It gives her the power and tools to bring a particular vision to life. Kiana feels so privileged to have the opportunity to practice and expand her skills in this profession with this incredibly humorous and clever show.

Manon Lemus, Art Director
Manon is the art director of “Brennan & Victoria Make Rent”. She’s passionate about production design, Toronto, and women in film so taking part in this series was a no-brainer. She can’t wait to bring the vision to the screen and hopes you love the project as much as she does.

 

Check out our perks and see how you can be part of making this project not only survive but thrive. 

Thank you for reading this far. We hope you can donate and most importantly we hope you watch the series.

If you have any questions or comments, contact: ossingtonandcollegeproductions@gmail.com. 

Follow our facebook page for updates: @brennanandvictoriamakerent

story:
Short Summary

About me:

  • Romeo Ortiz is a Graduate from the first film based High School in the United States, The Cinema School (TCS) and alumni at The Ghetto Film (GFS). Born October 25th in Queens, New York, Romeo’s passion for film emerged before his 4 years at TCS. Rather than being an average preteen, he stood his days inside creating his first cinematic pieces with his collectibles. This was the start of his production company, MAD Gothic Productions (MGP). Thanks to the unique, rigorous 8-month training from The Ghetto Film School his knowledge was extended even further in the art of filmmaking industry. At GFS Romeo took his first leap into his career in film when writing 2016, GFS Thesis project Genesis. Which was screened at the Paley Center For Media the following year. Romeo now leads with new profound confidence, independently and creatively crosses his comfort zone for the development and success of MAD Gothic Productions. 

 

  • Lani Martinez is a young adaptive artist who was born on August 27th in Bronx, New York. Lani’s art career began when she was only one year old, drawing stick figures with features like hair, eyes, and mouths. It was at this age that she was known as “advanced”, and even “gifted and talented”. Lani’s love for film, scriptwriting, and photography was developed in her first choice of high school, The Cinema School (TCS). Since then she has become an Award-Nominated Filmmaker with a film entitled Delirium, Showcased her Art pieces with The Fox and King which was showcased in the Bronx News Reporter, and more.  Lani now is developing "Messy Arts" and has her heart set on experimenting on her individual talents, art, and poetry.

Project plot for Episode 1.1:

  • Miranda watches her paintings come to life as they hijack her summer to warn her of an unknown evil that approaches the human world from what they call the "Wonderland"

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is $500 and this will go into production rentals such as lens and gear. It will also be going to securing locations, food for the crew and most importantly, film festival fees!  

The Impact

  • Any type of donation that is given will GREATLY impact the project and how it comes out. Since being in the indie film market, money is always a challenge when trying to get things moving! 

Risks & Challenges

  • The challenges of this project are time. Time is money and we understand this! With production, anything can happen but with our experience, we have the ability to overcome this challenge!  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign! Help spread the world!

story:
The pilot episode:

 

 

Above is the link where you may view the pilot episode of Faces In the Wasteland, which our production team made on a literal $0 budget. Our goal is to expand on this world with ten additional episodes, each episode between 15-20 mins focusing on a different individual and their life now in the aftermath of the apocalypse.

The series will be similarly influenced by various stories and forms of media such as The Road, The Last of Us, Fallout, and the first season of The Walking Dead. The production team behind it is a collection of both seasoned and new filmmakers employing the help of various actors across the state of Michigan to fill these roles, our goal to eventually have as diversified and unique of a cast as we can manage. This series is not only easily achievable, as you have seen with the pilot episode having been made for literally nothing, but we are able to finish and turn the series around in what we believe will be an extremely immediate amount of time as we have the majority of production prepared. We have what we feel is a unique collection of stories centered around various aspects of society and these would change in this fictitious world that we feel has not often been discussed before. Even the most minuscule of contributions will have such a great impact on our ability to see this through.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

 

What We Need & What You Get

What we are aiming for is $8,000. This $8,000 will fully cover all additional elements of production as well as increase our production value where we can begin to implement just under $1000 an episode in the series. And as you've seen, we are capable of delivering a more than competent product with literally no money whatsoever at the moment. These funds will be going solely into the production value of the series, which will include set building (marketplaces and towns), equipment rental (various lenses and improved sound equipment), and licensing and fees for arts supply their music. Our goal is just enough where we may still be making the series on a shoe string budget to give the series and appearance of gritty realness, but still simultaneously be able to take care of our cast and crew and provide viewers with an enjoyable and authentic labor of love.

We don't want to look at what we give back to someone for donating as a "reward", but as an abundant "thank you" with a gift for your aid. This includes digital copies, the chance to have a main character in the series be given your name (or a name of your choosing), or to even be in the series itself (and trust us, it would be more than just a meager "walk on" role).

Our plan is to make this series with whatever it is that we receive, so any and all amounts of donations we receive will still be put into the budget we do have for this project. The scope of the dream may just need to narrow some.

 

The Impact

We will be pitching this series to various streaming platforms, but money is not our goal. The ability to share and tell these stories, that is what we are hoping most for the chance to do. So if the series, for example, is never acquired for streaming, then we will stream it for free ourselves so that the show may be seen. Our work may be cut out for us and it may pose as a greater challenge, but we won't stop until we can share this experience.

Various members of our production team have not only worked on their own series before, but also written, directed, and distributed feature films as well (some of which can currently be viewed on Amazon, OnDemand, etc.). We are by no means experts, but we aren't just simply getting our feet wet for the first time around.

Risks & Challenges

There are innumerable risks when taking on any production, but the most common seen among those who have worked on lower budget productions is often failure of completion. Often teams become discouraged and find themselves unable to meet their goals. As we have shown you with our pilot episode above, we have the ability to finish every single one of these written episodes, and we will finish Faces In the Wasteland, even amongst our various productions currently in the process of being finished. We will just merely have to find ways to be creative and circumvent any and all of our obstacles.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, word of mouth is more valuable than you can know. Have a friend who enjoys science fiction or a family members who always starts that "if the world ended, what I would do is..."? Share this with them. Or tell us what WOULD peak your interest enough into donating, perhaps some stories or aspects of society and how they would change after the collapse of civilation. While the majority of the series is written, if we exceed our goal, we absolutely plan on expanding the universe of the story further. So feel free!

And as you've seen, we are capable of delivering a more than competent product with literally no money whatsoever at the moment. These funds will be going solely into the production value of the series, which will include set building (marketplaces and towns), equipment rental (various lenses and improved sound equipment), and licensing and fees for arts supply their music. Our goal is just enough where we may still be making the series on a shoe string budget to give the series and appearance of gritty realness, but still simultaneously be able to take care of our cast and crew and provide viewers with an enjoyable and authentic labor of love.
We don't want to look at what we give back to someone for donating as a "reward", but as an abundant "thank you" with a gift for your aid. This includes digital copies, the chance to have a main character in the series be given your name (or a name of your choosing), or to even be in the series itself (and trust us, it would be more than just a meager "walk on" role).
Our plan is to make this series with whatever it is that we receive, so any and all amounts of donations we receive will still be put into the budget we do have for this project. The scope of the dream may just need to narrow some.
 

The Impact
We will be pitching this series to various streaming platforms, but money is not our goal. The ability to share and tell these stories, that is what we are hoping most for the chance to do. So if the series, for example, is never acquired for streaming, then we will stream it for free ourselves so that the show may be seen. Our work may be cut out for us and it may pose as a greater challenge, but we won't stop until we can share this experience.
Various members of our production team have not only worked on their own series before, but also written, directed, and distributed feature films as well (some of which can currently be viewed on Amazon, OnDemand, etc.). We are by no means experts, but we aren't just simply getting our feet wet for the first time around.

Risks & Challenges
There are innumerable risks when taking on any production, but the most common seen among those who have worked on lower budget productions is often failure of completion. Often teams become discouraged and find themselves unable to meet their goals. As we have shown you with our pilot episode above, we have the ability to finish every single one of these written episodes, and we will finish Faces In the Wasteland, even amongst our various productions currently in the process of being finished. We will just merely have to find ways to be creative and circumvent any and all of our obstacles.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, word of mouth is more valuable than you can know. Have a friend who enjoys science fiction or a family members who always starts that "if the world ended, what I would do is..."? Share this with them. Or tell us what WOULD peak your interest enough into donating, perhaps some stories or aspects of society and how they would change after the collapse of civilation. While the majority of the series is written, if we exceed our goal, we absolutely plan on expanding the universe of the story further. So feel free!

story:
Like so many affected by the economic downturn, skip tracer Frank Briggs finds himself faced with an uncertain future. Seeing a new way to use his skills in a new light and keep himself financially afloat, Frank decided to becomes a skip maker. However Frank is not infallible, he gets things wrong just as much as he gets them right. But hey, who ever said pursuit of the American dream was easy?

Frank frees people from the burden of being stalked online. Whether it be a vengeful ex-lover, an abusive partner, a criminal looking to do harm to a potential witness or greedy family members looking for their share of a financial windfall. Frank provides his clients peace of mind by disguising their internet identity, allowing them the chance to live their lives without having to look over their shoulder.

Recognizing he needs help, he turns to his childhood friend, Milo Gephardt, a recovering addict familiar with the long arm of the law. Also assisting him Darby Shaffer, an ambitious journalist for the alt-newspaper, Philadelphia This Week and aspiring artist Alma Gutierrez. These four indivduals come to the aid of someone trying to disappear for a variety of reasons. Whether it be a woman try to elude her violent ex- lover, a young man who just won the lottery or an eye-witness of a violent crime. However, as the audience discovers, there are some people who should not be allowed to disappear.

 

Watch Episode 2 on YouTube

 


 

This is a serious genre piece with stakes and we want to give the audience a thrill every week.  Nothing is given with any of these characters. Some will live, some will die.  There should be a driving tension throughout each episode. We want stories that will appeal to women, men, the LGBQT community and we believe that can be best accomplished by clearly placing elements into an emotional and personal context.

Our goal for the first season of the web series was to create a quality story and make it easily accessible for our audience. Now one of our primary goals is to become a standard for dramatic narrative storytelling on the web series platform. I have unwavering faith that our second season can do that. The intent of the second season is to have a larger scope, more intimate story-lines and more dynamic, complex characters than the first season. Simply put, we are looking to outdo ourselves. The exciting part in all of this is that we have an established audience that is expecting all of this from us. 

 

THE CAST

 

THE CREW

Its true that creating digital content for the world wide web seem effortless and inexpensive, but the truth is that it isn't. So its time to turn to you, the people. Your generous contribution will go towards:

In addition to supporting HERRINGS financially, there are other ways you can help out! 

1) First and foremost, please SHARE the campaign through your social media accounts using the URL https://igg.me/at/herrings-season2 ! Every click and share helps! 

2) EMAIL your friends and groups who might be interested in this story! If you know someone who might really enjoy this film or appreciate the themes it explores, shoot them a quick email with a link to the campaign. 

3) Do you have a fun idea or item that you would like to DONATE as A PERK? If so, please let us know by emailing EMAIL HERE We would love to surprise our supporters with a new perk midway through the campaign. 

4) Make a MATCH. If you plan to donate to the campaign, consider offering to match the donations of others. Email us if you'd like to become a MATCHING DONOR. 

5) FOLLOW us on Facebook , Twitter, Instagram and don't forget to SUBSCRIBE to our YouTube channel!

story:
How did 'Out to Lunch' start?

Hi everyone! My name is Dylan Mask, i'm an actor in the city of Toronto and creator of the comedic Web Series 'Out to Lunch'. Two years ago I wrote episode 1 of the series to help keep me busy and focused while learning a new skill in between jobs. In order to reach your dream in this industry you must constantly be moving forward. Rather than sit around and wait for work I decided to create my own. My main objective with this series wasn't to become rich and famous but rather to create a series that everyone involved could be proud of and truly feel like they made a difference, while growing and learning at the same time.

I decided to self-fund the first 4 episodes in order to show future financial backers (YOU!) that this is more than just an idea. The response so far has been overwhelming, and I couldn't be more thankful to all those who have supported and shared the project thus far. 

I've managed to have an amazing cast/crew who is passionate and dedicated to the project. As you can see in episodes 1-4 the quality gets better and better as we grow together as a team. In order to keep the momentum rolling and finish in a timely manner we need your help!

By contributing to this project you're helping make a dream come true, while giving local talent-both in front and behind the camera- the chance to be noticed in an industry where all it takes is that one chance. Help me bring you episodes 5-8 and be a HUGE part of the exciting conclusion of 'Out to Lunch'.    

Crunching Numbers

Everyone needs a good laugh, sometimes that comes at a cost. Here is a breakdown of where your money will go:

GOAL: $5,000 (minimum goal)

$1,600- Do you see what I see? This will cover the wage of the camera crew in order to give you the best possible picture for 'Out to Lunch'.

$1,200- Can you hear us? This money goes to paying our very talented Sound Technician, because what good is great visuals when you can't hear what's being said!?

$800- Does this go here? These funds go towards paying our newest member to the team. The editor! All the cuts, graphics, and music play a huge role in bringing you a professional and cohesive finished product.

$400- Does this dress make my butt look big? This money goes towards hair, makeup, and wardrobe to make sure our cast looks presentable!

$500- Who's watching? All of this money goes towards promotion and festival submission so we can reach as big an audience as possible!

$500- Are we there yet? I'm starving. This last chunk will help with transportation for actors and crew as well as keep them fed while filming. As Shakespeare once said "Doth not act good on an empty stomach."

Above & Beyond:

Now you may have noticed that none of that money goes to pay the actors. That's because the ENTIRE cast is volunteering their time to be a part of this project. That being said here is a quick breakdown of what happens if we surpass our goal or fall short:

Surpass: Every dollar we raise above our goal will go directly back into the production. First up is our amazing cast! After they are compensated for the time dedicated we can focus more funds on festival submissions and promotion to help 'Out to Lunch' be seen worldwide!

Fall Short: If we fall short of our goal we will use every cent we did manage to raise to continue production as far as we can. Once the money raised runs out we turn to bake sales, raffles, and bikini car washes to get the rest. *please note, nobody wants to see three grown men washing cars in bikinis.*

PERKS:

We've got some amazing "Thank You!" perks for you to claim based on the amount you decide to donate. Any amount is appreciated greatly, but for certain levels of donations you'll get a great gift that's personalized from US to YOU! It can be as simple as a shout-out on our social media pages or as big as a walk on role in the Finale! (some conditions apply on that last one).

The Road Less Travelled 

'Out to Lunch' flirts with the run-time of a full length TV series (episode 1: 7 mins, episode 2-4: 10-12 mins). I did this intentionally because I wanted to create something that felt real to the audience. A series that would get you invested in the character and watch the story grow. It's risky because with a lower budget and the main outlet being online you really have to captivate your viewers right off the bat and then keep them engaged. That's especially hard to do in this genre.

Comedy is one of the-if not- toughest genres to write, execute, film, and edit. So many factors are taken into equation when creating one. Almost everyone can relate to being afraid of an axe wielding maniac, and almost everyone can find some form of connection in a love story. With comedy, you're hoping to connect with 50% of your audience. There is something special about being able to make someone laugh. For those few seconds they forget about what's going on around them and just live in that moment. 

Why 'Out to Lunch'?

A lot of people ask how the series came to be called 'Out to Lunch'. Well the answer is simple. I needed a creative catchy name that would capture the essence of the show itself. The phrase "Out to lunch..." is used to describe someone who is: Unaware of or inattentive to present conditions. This relates directly to the main character Dylan Crawford. He lives in a world where negatives don't appear negative and the impossible seems extremely possible. The audience then attributes his personality to being "out to lunch" rather than ignorant, or naive. Although sometimes he can be the latter.

Other Ways You Can Help

Donating isn't the only way to help us reach our goal! You can help us by sharing this campaign and series with family and friends and follow us on our various social platforms:

YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/c/behinddamask      

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/OTLtheseries

Instagram: @OTL_theseries

Twitter: @OTL_theseries

story:
Why am I Doing This?

Living in North Carolina has not been the best experience for me, career-wise.  I had a spiritual epiphany two years ago.  I was told I had no choice, I had to return to acting, writing, and comedy.  Soon after, I found myself without any income, very little social life, and submerged in a city with a very limited professional arts community who didn't know what in the world to do with me.  So, I applied to grad school and was accepted into the only program I wanted to enroll...the University of Georgia Grady College of Journalism & Mass Communication MFA Screenwriting Program.  The minute I walked on campus I knew I made one of the best decisions of my life!

At the first MFA residency, I met an empowering woman, Jessie Kahnweiler.  She made sure to tell me at the end of that week I had no more room for excuses and had to produce my web series as soon as possible.  The issue was I had no money and no crew.  Well, over the course of six months I met some really cool actors, a DP, a photographer, and a director.  This summer I was blessed to talk to two people who told me they would help me on this project with editing and marketing.  So, August 6th (one year after Jessie's pep talk), it is official, I am in preproduction mode. 

What are the Details of the Show?

The pilot episode will be about 15 minutes.  It will introduce my life in Raleigh and end with the realization that I have to make living here work and still honor my professional performing arts career.

It is a scripted show with some improvisation.  I have to infuse improvisation.  I'm an improvising actor who graduated from The Second City-Chicago's Conservatory.  That was a shameless acting resume plug.  I'm a Capricorn.  I have to do it every now and then.

When and Where Do We Film?

We are filming for two days, September 30th and October 1st, in Raleigh.

Who's a Part of the Production?

Rebecca Jackson-Artis (Me!) - Producer/Screenwriter/Actor

Brittany Walton - Executive Producer/Director

Pete Stone - Editor

Tracy Fulce-Gentle - Marketing

Why Do I Need $5,000?

  • $1,500 for the Director of Photography and Stills Photographer
  • $500 to pay my actors (there will be three actors for the first episode-1 actor has a large role)
  • $500 to pay the editor
  • $500 to pay the marketing professional
  • $500 for set design
  • $1,500 for props, food, location fees, travel, music (theme song), and administrative costs

What's the Benefit of Donating?

You get to see your name in the credits under THANK YOU!
